Kahneman's research on cognitive ease shows that repeated tasks should become easier with practice, but a table where the target row shifts downward each week never develops the spatial consistency needed for System 1 recognition. The guest is forced into a System 2 scan on every single visit -- parsing row after row -- when they should be performing a System 1 glance at a fixed, visually prominent element.
elements.solution: Create a clear visual hierarchy where the current/next stay occupies a hero card with dramatically different visual treatment from all other stays. The hero card uses a white surface (#ffffff / --bg-white) with an elevated shadow (--shadow-md) and the accent purple left border (--secondary-purple, 3px) to create a 'this is your focus' signal. It sits above the fold, always in the same position regardless of how many weeks have passed. Completed stays below collapse into a muted summary row using --bg-light (#f9fafb) with --text-light-gray for the count. Future stays use the same muted treatment. The status badge on the hero card uses color-coded backgrounds: In Progress = --secondary-purple with white text, Completed = --status-success-light with --status-success-text, Not Started = --bg-light-gray with --text-gray. The hero card is the only element at full visual intensity; everything else is visually receded. This creates a System 1 focal point: the eye lands on the hero card because it is the only high-contrast, elevated element on the page.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 392-408
evidence.quote: Stays Table: Columns: Week #, Period (date range), Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed), Actions. Available Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: The flat table design gives 'No action available' rows the same visual weight as actionable rows. The guest's eye must distinguish between 'Review' (important) and 'No action available' (noise) across 13 rows, with no visual differentiation to guide the scan.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes.
evidence.insight: A hero card in a fixed position becomes a System 1 pattern after 2-3 visits: the guest knows exactly where to look without scanning. A table where the current row shifts downward each week defeats skill acquisition because the spatial target moves.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker checks the Stays Manager on Monday morning before heading to the property. Their System 2 is allocated to work. The hero card must deliver the answer in a single glance -- the visual hierarchy must make the current week unmissable without cognitive effort.

typography: Inter 600 20px (hero card week number)
Inter 400 14px (hero card date range)
Inter 600 12px (status badge)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Hero card: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 16.1:1. Status badge: white (#ffffff) on --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) = 6.4:1. Muted summary: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-light (#f9fafb) = 4.7:1. All pass AA for normal text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye lands on the hero card first because it is the only elevated, full-contrast surface. The left purple border provides a color accent that anchors attention. Status badge is the second fixation point because it is the only colored element within the card. Muted collapsed sections are peripheral -- visible but not competing for first-glance attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data.' The hero card delivers real data (this week, these dates, this status) in a warm, non-corporate format. The purple left border connects to the brand accent without overwhelming. Taste model: 'The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey.' The hero card adapts to the current week automatically -- it is relentlessly personalized, never generic.

coherence_note.conflict: The existing library element specifies warm off-white backgrounds (bg #f6f4f0) and white surface cards (#ffffff) as the universal visual foundation, with forest green (#2d5a3d) as the accent. The new guest-run elements introduce a different color vocabulary: --secondary-purple, --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3), --status-success-light (#E6F5EE), --bg-light (#f9fafb), --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6). The new elements reference Inter and Outfit fonts, while the library specifies Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono. The purple accent and the gray-blue background tones (#f9fafb, #f3f4f6) may conflict with the warm neutral palette established in tokens.json.
coherence_note.recommendation: The new guest-run elements should be reconciled with tokens.json before merging into the library. Options: (1) Add the new tokens (--secondary-purple, --status-warning-light, --bg-light) to tokens.json if they represent intentional extensions of the design system. (2) Translate the new elements' color references to existing token equivalents (e.g., --secondary-purple may map to accent or accent-bright; --status-warning-light may map to signal-warn-bg). (3) Replace Inter font references with the established Outfit sans-serif from tokens.json. The new elements' visual logic (hero card elevation, status badge color coding, financial hierarchy) is sound -- the conflict is in token naming, not in design intent.

elements.title: Schedule-First Listing Cards: Lead with Pattern Fit, Not Property Features
elements.problem: The search results page shows listing cards with property photos, location, title, room configuration, host name, and two pricing displays ('Starting at $235/night' and '$442.26/night based on selected schedule'). This is a feature-first hierarchy designed for vacation booking. But the Split Lease guest's primary filter is schedule compatibility, not property features. Bryant describes the core matching challenge: 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability' (10:17-10:27). The guest who needs Monday-Thursday nights first needs to know: does this listing have those nights available? At what cost for my specific pattern? For how long? The photos, amenities, and room configuration are secondary to schedule fit. Kahneman's limited attention budget principle predicts that every listing card that leads with photos and features before confirming schedule fit wastes the guest's finite evaluation capacity on properties that may be incompatible.
elements.solution: Restructure listing cards to lead with schedule fit information: (1) First element: a compact schedule compatibility indicator showing which of the guest's selected days are available at this property. Visual: the S M T W T F S day buttons with available days highlighted and unavailable days crossed out or dimmed. (2) Second element: the calculated cost for the guest's specific schedule, shown as a monthly equivalent ('$1,850/month for your Mon-Thu pattern'). (3) Third element: property photo, name, and location. (4) Fourth element: room configuration and host info. The CTA changes from 'Submit Proposal' to 'View Listing' if the schedule fit is partial, and 'Submit Proposal' if the schedule fit is complete. This reorders the card to match the guest's decision tree: can I use this property on my days? Can I afford it on my schedule? Does it look right? Is the host trustworthy?

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern, which we see... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability.
evidence.insight: Availability matching is the core challenge. A listing that looks perfect in every other dimension but does not have the guest's required days is a wasted evaluation. Leading with schedule fit eliminates this waste.

evidence.quote: Would you prefer me to come to you with a guest, even if it wouldn't work for your exact listing availability as it's displayed? -- No.
evidence.insight: Nneka will not accept guests whose schedules do not match her availability. This is a hard constraint, not a preference. If the host will reject mismatched guests, showing those listings to the guest wastes everyone's time. Schedule fit is a pass/fail gate that must be evaluated before any other property attribute.

evidence.quote: You dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities, and if you try to go beyond your budget, you will fail.
evidence.insight: Each listing card evaluated by the guest draws from the same finite attention budget. A card that leads with photos draws attention to visual evaluation before the guest knows if the schedule is compatible. When the guest discovers incompatibility after photo evaluation, the attention spent on photos is wasted and cannot be recovered. Leading with schedule fit preserves the attention budget for compatible listings.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 37-53
evidence.quote: Each card shows: Property photo carousel, Location, Property title, Type and capacity, Room configuration, Host name and verification badge, Two pricing displays: Starting rate: 'Starting at $235/night', Calculated rate: '$442.26/night' (based on selected schedule).
evidence.insight: The current card hierarchy mirrors Airbnb: photo first, location second, price third. But Split Lease's differentiation is schedule-based matching, not property-based browsing. The card hierarchy should reflect the platform's unique value proposition: schedule fit first, then price in the guest's format, then property details.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: schedule compatibility indicator (which of the guest's selected days are available). Secondary: monthly cost for the guest's specific pattern. Tertiary: property photo, name, and location. Quaternary: room configuration, host info, and verification badges.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On the listing card (search results): schedule fit indicator + monthly cost + small property photo. All visible without interaction. On card tap/click (listing detail page): full property information, larger photos, amenities, house rules, full pricing calculator. The card-level information answers 'Should I look closer?' The detail page answers 'Should I propose?'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 data points per listing card: schedule fit visual, monthly cost, property photo thumbnail, location. Two pricing displays ('starting at' and 'calculated') collapse into one: the calculated monthly cost for the guest's selected pattern. If the schedule is incompatible, the card is visually muted or deprioritized rather than removed (preserving the guest's sense of selection breadth).
scan_order: Schedule fit indicator: day buttons showing compatibility (System 1: 'Does this work for my days?', under 2 seconds)
Monthly cost for selected pattern (System 1: 'Can I afford this?', 2-3 seconds)
Property photo and location (System 1: 'Does this look right and is it in the right area?', 3-5 seconds)
Host info and verification badge (System 2: 'Is this host trustworthy?', 5-7 seconds, only if prior checks pass)
exclude: Two separate pricing displays on the same card ('starting at' and 'calculated'). Show one price: the calculated monthly cost for the guest's selected schedule.
Property photo as the dominant card element when schedule compatibility is uncertain. Schedule fit must visually precede or equal photo prominence.
Listings that are completely schedule-incompatible displayed at the same prominence as compatible listings. Incompatible listings should be visually deprioritized.
'Submit Proposal' CTA on cards where the schedule is only partially compatible. Partial compatibility should prompt 'View Listing' to encourage evaluation before commitment.

coherence_note.conflict: The existing library element prescribes the agent's identity as the primary trust frame across all platform communications (every notification comes FROM the agent, the platform speaks as an extension of Bryant). The new guest-run listing card element (communicates-006) prescribes schedule-first listing cards where the primary signal is schedule compatibility, with host name/info relegated to quaternary position. This creates a tension: the library says the human agent should be the most prominent trust signal on every screen, but the new guest-run search results deprioritize the host's identity in favor of functional matching data.
coherence_note.recommendation: Clarify that the agent-continuity-frame principle applies to the specific user's assigned agent relationship, not universally to all screens. For guest search results, the relevant human signal is the host's verification status (a trust badge), not the Split Lease agent's identity. The host's name and verification badge are appropriate at quaternary hierarchy on listing cards, while schedule fit and pricing are primary. No contradiction exists if the principle is scoped correctly: agent identity is primary for the user who has a personal agent relationship (the host); listing-level trust signals (host verification) are appropriate for the guest evaluating multiple listings.

elements.title: Make Replace, Add, and Remove Financially Legible at the Moment of Choice
elements.problem: The guest journey currently treats all date changes as a single category, but the Nneka call reveals that 'replace' and 'add' have fundamentally different pricing implications. Bryant asks: 'If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something you would be open to?' and Nneka responds that additions would be at a 'different rate' (07:22-07:45). Nneka also states that replacing dates at the old rate is 'not working financially' due to seasonal pricing changes (03:33-04:26). This means: (a) replacing dates may trigger a price adjustment if the new dates fall in a different pricing season, (b) adding dates is always at the current market rate, and (c) removing dates triggers a refund calculation. The guest currently has no way to understand these distinctions before acting. Kahneman's research on System 1 associative coherence shows that the mind does not automatically distinguish between similar-seeming actions with different consequences. A guest who thinks 'change my dates' is performing one simple mental operation; the platform must not force them to perform three separate cognitive evaluations to understand the financial implications of replace vs. add vs. remove.
elements.solution: When the guest initiates a date change, present the three options (Replace, Add, Remove) as a single choice screen where each option shows its financial consequence in one number: (1) Replace: 'Swap Oct 15 for Oct 22. Price difference: +$0' or '+$12 (seasonal adjustment).' (2) Add: 'Add Oct 22. Cost: $85 (current rate).' (3) Remove: 'Remove Oct 15. Refund: $73.' The guest selects one option and sees the specific financial impact before confirming. No mental arithmetic. No ambiguity about which action costs money and which saves money. The Flexibility Score (already in the Date Change section of the Stays Manager) should be visible but not positioned as a guilt mechanism; it should explain what it means ('Your host has accommodated 4 of 5 change requests') rather than just showing a percentage.

evidence.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to and if so, would that be at a different rate... it would be a different rate.
evidence.insight: Even the Split Lease team must explicitly ask about the pricing distinction between replace and add. If the internal team needs clarification, the guest certainly cannot be expected to understand this without explicit presentation.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was... therefore I am not able to do that.
evidence.insight: Seasonal pricing means that even a 'replace' action can have a cost delta. The guest who thinks they are doing a simple swap may face a price increase because the replacement dates are in a higher-priced season. This surprise must be eliminated by showing the delta before confirmation.

evidence.quote: Your System 1 made as much sense as possible of the situation... by linking the words in a causal story; it evaluated the possible threat... and created a context for future developments.
evidence.insight: System 1 treats 'change dates' as a single coherent action. It does not automatically decompose this into three different actions with three different financial implications. The platform must present the decomposition explicitly, with financial consequences attached to each option, so the guest's System 1 can evaluate each option as a distinct story with a clear outcome.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 419-428 (Change Types and Pricing)
evidence.quote: Change Types: Add nights (guest pays more), Remove nights (guest gets refund), Swap dates. Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: The UI design already distinguishes the three change types, but the pricing section uses abstract labels ('buying back nights,' 'fair market rate calculation') that require System 2 translation. The guest needs concrete dollar amounts for their specific situation, not category definitions.

elements.user_goal: Understand exactly what each type of date change will cost me (or save me) before I commit, without performing any mental arithmetic or reading pricing policy documentation.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate post-change pricing disputes and support tickets by making financial consequences transparent at the moment of decision. Ensure seasonal pricing adjustments are understood and accepted before they are applied.
elements.time_budget: The guest should comprehend the financial impact of their chosen change type within 5 seconds of seeing the options. One number per option. No scrolling, no expanding sections, no tooltips required.
anti_goals: DO NOT use abstract pricing labels ('fair market rate,' 'seasonal adjustment') without showing the specific dollar amount for this specific change.
DO NOT present the three change types without their financial consequences. Type and cost must be a single visual unit.
DO NOT assume the guest knows that 'replace' can cost money if seasonal rates differ. Show the delta even when it is $0, to build trust that the platform is transparent.
DO NOT use the Flexibility Score as a pressure mechanism to discourage date changes. Display it as context, not as a barrier.
elements.success_metric: Post-change pricing dispute rate: percentage of completed date changes that result in a support ticket or complaint about unexpected pricing. Target: below 5%. Secondary: guest comprehension rate measured by whether the guest's selected change type matches their stated intent (survey sample).

coherence_note.gap_filled: Financial legibility of replace/add/remove date change types. No existing library element addresses the semantic and financial distinction between change types. This element fills a gap in the pricing display architecture by extending the single-sum principle to micro-financial decisions within the active lease.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Directly evidenced by Bryant's confusion about replace vs. add pricing (nneka-call.txt, 07:22-07:45) and Nneka's inability to honor old rates for rescheduled dates (03:33-04:26).

elements.title: Protect the Guest's Cognitive Budget by Batching Active-Lease Administrative Tasks
elements.problem: The Stays Manager asks the guest to perform multiple administrative actions per stay: Review the stay (rate cleanliness, accuracy, communication, write text), Upload Photos (document property condition), and Report Issues. Over a 13-week lease, this is potentially 39 separate prompts. Each prompt is a System 2 task: the guest must recall the specific stay, evaluate their experience, compose a rating or description, and submit. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that sequential self-control tasks drain from a shared pool. A hybrid worker returning from a long workday to the Stays Manager faces administrative tasks that compete with the same depleted System 2 resources they used for work. The result is predictable: guests complete reviews for the first few weeks, then compliance drops as depletion accumulates. The per-stay review process treats each week as equally important, but the guest's cognitive capacity for administrative tasks degrades over the lease duration -- precisely when their feedback about the long-term living experience becomes most valuable.
elements.solution: Batch administrative tasks to match the guest's natural energy rhythms rather than the platform's per-week data structure: (1) Instead of prompting for a review after every stay, batch reviews at natural intervals: after Week 4 (end of first payment cycle), at the midpoint of the lease, and after the final stay. Three thoughtful reviews are more valuable than 13 perfunctory ones. (2) Photo uploads should be prompted once at move-in (document initial condition) and once at move-out (document final condition), not weekly. Mid-lease photos are optional and available on demand but never prompted. (3) Issue reporting is the exception: this must be available immediately and prominently at any time, because issues are time-sensitive. But the 'Report Issue' button should be a persistent element, not a per-stay action buried in a table row. (4) Each batched review moment should take no more than 2 minutes and should present pre-filled context: 'Your stay over the past 4 weeks covered Oct 1-25, across 4 weeks. How was it?' This eliminates the recall burden of week-by-week evaluation.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 453-459 (Stay Review Process)
evidence.quote: After each stay: 'Review' button becomes active. Guest rates property/host. Rates on: Cleanliness, accuracy, communication. Writes text review (optional).
evidence.insight: The current design activates a review prompt after every single stay (every week). For a 13-week lease, this is 13 review prompts. Each requires the guest to recall the specific week, evaluate three dimensions, and optionally write text. This is a classic ego depletion cascade: each review draws from the same depleted pool, making subsequent reviews less likely and less thoughtful.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around. The phenomenon has been named ego depletion.
evidence.insight: The review fatigue pattern mirrors Kahneman's ego depletion cascade exactly. The first review is completed with care. By Week 5, the guest's System 2 has been depleted by four prior reviews (plus their work responsibilities), and the review either becomes perfunctory (5 stars, no text) or is skipped entirely.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a working professional visiting 4-5 nights per week. They arrive at the property after work and leave for work in the morning. Their cognitive budget for platform administrative tasks is minimal -- it competes directly with work responsibilities. Batching reviews to natural break points respects this constraint.

evidence.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
evidence.insight: Kahneman recommends dividing tasks into easy steps -- but the current design does the opposite: it creates too many easy steps (13 weekly reviews) that in aggregate become an overwhelming administrative burden. The solution is not more steps; it is fewer, better-timed steps that capture the same information with less total effort.

elements.user_goal: Provide meaningful feedback about my living experience without feeling like I am filling out a weekly survey. Administrative tasks should respect my time and arrive when I have something meaningful to say.
elements.company_goal: Increase review completion rates and review quality by reducing review fatigue. Capture higher-quality feedback at natural reflection points rather than low-quality feedback at forced weekly intervals.
elements.time_budget: Each batched review moment: under 2 minutes. Total administrative time over a 13-week lease: under 10 minutes (3 reviews x 2 minutes + 2 photo sessions x 2 minutes). Current design theoretical maximum: 13 reviews x 3 minutes = 39 minutes.
anti_goals: DO NOT prompt for a review after every single stay. Weekly review prompts create fatigue that reduces both completion rate and review quality.
DO NOT treat photo uploads as a weekly obligation. Move-in and move-out photos serve the damage deposit function; weekly photos serve no clear purpose and create busywork.
DO NOT batch issue reporting. Issues are time-sensitive and must be reportable immediately from a persistent, visible button.
DO NOT eliminate the ability to review individual weeks for guests who want to. The batch approach is the default; the per-week option is available on demand.
elements.success_metric: Review completion rate: percentage of lease periods that receive at least one completed review. Target: above 70% (vs. current per-week completion rate, likely below 30% by end of lease). Secondary: average review word count above 20 words (indicating thoughtful feedback rather than perfunctory submission).

coherence_note.gap_filled: Batched administrative tasks (reviews, photo uploads) to prevent ego depletion cascade during active lease. No existing library element addresses the review fatigue problem. The library's depletion-aware design (works-002) addresses multi-step process completion but not the long-term administrative burden of a 13-week recurring interaction pattern.
coherence_note.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The evidence is based on Kahneman's ego depletion theory applied to a 13-week review cycle. No direct call evidence that guests actually experience review fatigue -- this is a theoretical extension. However, the design principle (batch administrative tasks at natural reflection points) is well-grounded and low-risk.

elements.title: Surface Real-Time Availability Inside the Guest's Decision Flow
elements.problem: Host availability on Split Lease depends on external platforms, primarily Airbnb. Nneka confirms: 'Airbnb. I have some of them today. If I worked, then it automatically updates on' (05:06-05:44). Bryant asks about screenshots of availability as a workaround (05:27). The guest has no visibility into this dependency. When Brad requests a reschedule, his success depends on Nneka's Airbnb calendar -- a system he cannot see and may not know exists. This creates a pattern of opaque rejection: the guest requests a date, the host says no (because Airbnb shows the date as booked), and the guest experiences this as arbitrary hostility rather than a factual constraint. During search and listing evaluation, the same problem manifests differently: the guest sees a listing that appears available, but the actual available dates are a subset constrained by the host's cross-platform bookings. Kahneman's violation model predicts that when 'an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains,' the guest's trust is damaged. The guest's model is: 'if the listing is on Split Lease, the dates are available on Split Lease.' The reality violates this model.
elements.solution: Integrate host availability into every guest-facing decision point where dates matter: (1) In search results, show only dates that are actually available (synced from the host's calendar, including Airbnb). Never show a listing as available for dates that are blocked on the host's external calendar. (2) On the listing evaluation page, the day-of-week selector should gray out unavailable dates rather than allowing the guest to select them and discover unavailability later. (3) In the Stays Manager Date Change flow, show available dates inline so the guest never requests a date that will be rejected. 'Available dates this week: Mon, Tue, Wed (Thu-Fri booked).' (4) When availability changes after a guest has submitted a proposal or change request, notify the guest immediately rather than letting the request sit in limbo. The pattern is: never let the guest invest cognitive effort in evaluating or requesting a date that is not available.

evidence.quote: Airbnb. I have some of them today. If I worked, then it automatically updates on... you guys have the most up to date... we can update that.
evidence.insight: Host availability is managed on Airbnb and synced (or manually updated) to Split Lease. The guest interacts with Split Lease but their success depends on Airbnb data they cannot see. This hidden dependency creates unpredictable failures.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability.
evidence.insight: Bryant acknowledges that availability matching between guest usage patterns and host calendars is a fundamental challenge. The platform's search and evaluation phases do not currently surface this matching problem, forcing the guest to discover incompatibility through trial and rejection.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains. In that world, lamps do not jump, cats do not bark.
evidence.insight: In the guest's mental model, 'listed on Split Lease' means 'available on Split Lease.' A rejection due to Airbnb conflicts violates this model, triggering the same surprise-and-suspicion response as Kahneman's lamps-jumping example. The platform must prevent this violation by never showing unavailable options.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 436-438 (Date Change Actions)
evidence.quote: Request Changes button - Initiate modification. Accept/Reject incoming requests. Remove expired requests.
evidence.insight: The current 'Request Changes' flow allows the guest to submit a change that may be rejected due to availability constraints the guest cannot see. Showing available dates before the guest submits eliminates rejected requests and the frustration they cause.

elements.user_goal: Only see dates and listings that are actually available, so I never waste time evaluating, requesting, or waiting for something that was never possible.
elements.company_goal: Reduce rejected proposals and date change requests by surfacing availability constraints before the guest commits cognitive effort. Decrease time-to-match by eliminating false-positive availability in search results.
elements.time_budget: Availability data must load within the page load of any date-related view. The guest should never need to submit a request and wait to learn if the date was available. Availability is a prerequisite to the request, not a response to it.
anti_goals: DO NOT show listings in search results for date ranges where the host has no availability. This wastes the guest's evaluation effort and damages platform credibility.
DO NOT allow the guest to request a date change to a date that is known to be unavailable. Gray out or remove unavailable dates from the picker.
DO NOT expose the complexity of cross-platform availability syncing to the guest. The guest should never see 'this date is blocked on Airbnb.' They should simply not see the date as an option.

DO NOT rely on manual availability updates. If the sync with external calendars is not real-time, show a confidence indicator ('Availability last updated 2 hours ago') rather than presenting stale data as current.
elements.success_metric: Date change rejection rate: percentage of guest-initiated date changes rejected due to availability. Target: below 10% (indicating the guest almost never requests an unavailable date). Secondary: search-to-proposal conversion rate improvement, measured by the reduction in listings viewed before a proposal is submitted.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Real-time availability surfacing inside the guest's decision flow. No existing library element addresses the Airbnb cross-listing availability dependency that creates opaque rejection patterns. This fills a critical search and active_lease gap where the guest's success depends on a system they cannot see.
coherence_note.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Directly evidenced by Nneka's Airbnb cross-listing confirmation (05:06-05:44) and Bryant's workaround of asking for availability screenshots (05:27). The availability opacity problem is well-documented but the solution (real-time sync surfaced in every date-related view) has significant technical implications beyond UI design.

elements.title: Current-Week Hero Card: Invert the Stays Table so Today's Answer Comes First
elements.problem: The Stays Manager presents all stays as a flat table with columns for Week #, Period, Status, and Actions. A guest with a 13-week lease sees 13 rows of equal visual weight. To answer the only question that matters on a weekly visit -- 'What do I need to do right now?' -- the guest must visually scan the table, skip past completed weeks, identify the current or next upcoming week, read its status, and determine the appropriate action. This is a System 2 scan task imposed on a page visited every week for 3+ months. Kahneman's research on cognitive ease demonstrates that repeated tasks should become easier with practice, but a table that grows with completed rows becomes harder to scan over time -- the opposite of skill acquisition. The hybrid worker target persona (Bryant at 10:17-12:17: 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... 2-3 month commitments typical') checks this page on Monday mornings before heading to the property. Their System 2 is allocated to work responsibilities, not to parsing a data table. Layer 1 (works-003) identified the process problem; this element defines the information hierarchy that solves it.
elements.solution: Structure the Stays Manager page around a single hero card for the current or next actionable stay, with all other information subordinated. The hero card answers the guest's weekly question in a single glance: the week number, the date range, the status, and the one action available (if any). Completed stays collapse into a summary line ('6 stays completed'). Future stays collapse into a count ('6 weeks remaining'). The full table is available as a secondary view for guests who want the complete picture, but it is never the default. The information hierarchy is: (1) current week card, (2) pending alerts (date changes, payments), (3) summary of past and future. This mirrors how a calendar app shows today's events first, not January 1st.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 392-408
evidence.quote: Stays (X) - Individual visit tracking. Stays Table: Columns: Week #, Period (date range), Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed), Actions. Available Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: The current design gives Week 1 (completed two months ago) and Week 13 (three weeks from now) the same visual weight. The guest must scan past irrelevant rows to find the relevant one. 'No action available' appears for all future stays, creating visual noise that dilutes the signal of actionable items.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The primary guest persona visits this page weekly for 2-3 months. Each visit is a micro-interaction: check status, see if anything needs attention, leave. The page must be optimized for this repeated micro-interaction, not for a comprehensive management session.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: A hero card that always appears in the same position with the same structure becomes a System 1 pattern after 2-3 visits: the guest knows where to look and what to expect. A table that changes row count each week never becomes automatic because the target location shifts downward with each completed stay.

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... there is little strain... Just like a stroll. Accelerating beyond my strolling speed completely changes the experience.
evidence.insight: The weekly Stays Manager check should be a cognitive 'stroll.' Scanning a 13-row table to find the current week is a cognitive 'jog' that the guest is forced into every single visit. Over 13 weeks, this unnecessary acceleration accumulates into resentment toward the platform.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current/next stay hero card (week number, dates, status, single action). Secondary: alert banner for pending date changes, upcoming payments, or host messages. Tertiary: collapsed summary of completed and upcoming stays with expandable detail.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on page load: hero card with current week status and action. On scroll: alert area for pending items. On tap/expand: full stays table for comprehensive view. The hero card is never hidden, never scrolled past, and never visually subordinated to the table.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One card, one status, one action on the primary view. Maximum 3 data points above the fold: week number, date range, action button. The full 13-row table is accessible but requires deliberate expansion.
scan_order: Hero card: week number and date range (System 1 recognition: 'This is my week', under 1 second)
Status badge on hero card: In Progress, Completed, or Not Started (System 1 assessment: 'Am I good?', 1-2 seconds)
Action button: Review, Upload Photos, or no action needed (System 1 decision: 'Do I need to do anything?', 2-3 seconds)
Alert area: pending date changes or payment reminders (System 2 engagement only if present, 3-5 seconds)
exclude: Flat table as the default view. The table is a secondary view accessed by deliberate expansion.
Completed stays displayed at the same visual weight as the current stay. Past stays collapse into a one-line summary.
Future stays listed individually with 'No action available.' Future stays are a count, not a list.
Any information that requires the guest to scroll to find the current week.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Current-week hero card information architecture for the Stays Manager. Extends the library's anchor-then-advance principle (communicates-001) to a recurring weekly context rather than a one-time onboarding flow.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. The hero card inverts the flat table to match the guest's weekly micro-interaction pattern. Evidence is strong from both the journey map (table structure) and Kahneman (cognitive ease for repeated tasks).

elements.title: Pre-Commitment Rate Anchoring: Show Seasonal Variability Before the Guest Locks a Price in Memory
elements.problem: Nneka reveals that her original rate was $1,170-$1,175/month but seasonal pricing means rescheduled dates are more expensive (03:33-04:26). This creates a trust-destroying pattern: the guest commits at one price, then encounters a different price when rescheduling mid-lease. Kahneman's anchoring research demonstrates that the first number a person sees becomes their reference point; deviations from that anchor are experienced as gains or losses relative to it, not as objective market values. The listing page currently shows a single nightly rate ($300.98) and a single 4-week rent ($3,611.79). If the guest's lease spans two pricing seasons, they anchor on the rate shown at listing evaluation and experience any seasonal increase during the active lease as a penalty -- even if the higher rate was disclosed somewhere in the fine print. The information architecture must prevent this anchoring trap by surfacing rate variability before the guest's System 1 locks onto a single number.
elements.solution: At listing evaluation, when the guest's selected dates span a period where rates may change, show the rate range rather than a single rate: 'Your rate: $280-$301/night depending on season. Oct-Dec: $280/night. Jan-Feb: $301/night.' At proposal creation, the cost summary shows the blended rate and flags any seasonal variation: 'Your 20-week reservation spans two rate periods. Weeks 1-12: $280/night. Weeks 13-20: $301/night. Total: $11,738.' At acceptance, the confirmation includes a one-line clause: 'Date changes are priced at the rate for the new dates. See your rate schedule above.' In the Stays Manager, the Payment Schedule labels each period with its applicable rate so the guest can see which rate governs which weeks. The pattern is: never let the guest anchor on a single rate when their lease will encounter multiple rates.

evidence.quote: Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was... therefore I am not able to do that... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: The host cannot honor the original rate for rescheduled dates because seasonal pricing has increased. If the guest was never shown that rates vary by season, they experience the increase as a broken promise rather than a market adjustment. Pre-commitment disclosure transforms a trust violation into an expected and accepted variable.

evidence.quote: By providing him the flexibility, you're not leaving the days available that were booked before... by pushing them back, it's sort of taking days away that were previously available.
evidence.insight: Rescheduling has an opportunity cost (blocked dates cannot be rebooked at higher seasonal rates). The guest who understands why rates differ by season can accept the logic. The guest who anchored on a single rate cannot.

evidence.quote: Now that you have measured the lines, you -- your System 2 -- have a new belief: you know that the lines are equally long. But you still see the bottom line as longer.
evidence.insight: Even after learning that seasonal rates differ, the guest will still feel that the original rate is the 'real' rate and the higher rate is an overcharge. This is a cognitive illusion that cannot be eliminated, only anticipated. The solution is not to convince the guest that the higher rate is fair (that fights the illusion) but to prevent the single-rate anchor from forming in the first place (that avoids the illusion).

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 83-106
evidence.quote: Nightly Rate Display: Large: '$300.98 /night'. Updates dynamically. Interactive Pricing: System recalculates when guest changes days selected, duration, move-in date.
evidence.insight: The listing page already recalculates price dynamically when the guest changes inputs. It has the infrastructure to show rate variation by date range. The missing piece is not technical capability but information architecture: the page shows a single output rate rather than a rate schedule that reveals seasonal variation.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the rate for the guest's selected dates, shown as a range if it spans seasons ('$280-$301/night'). Secondary: a compact rate schedule showing which rate applies to which portion of their stay. Tertiary: an explanation of why rates differ (seasonal demand, host pricing decisions) available on demand.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At listing evaluation: rate range displayed whenever the selected duration spans a pricing boundary. At proposal creation: blended cost breakdown by rate period. At acceptance: one-line seasonal pricing acknowledgment in the confirmation summary. In the Stays Manager: rate label on each Payment Schedule row so the guest can trace which rate applies to each payment.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 rate figures visible at listing evaluation (low end and high end of the range). Maximum 3 rate periods in the proposal breakdown (most leases will span 1-2 seasons). The rate schedule is a compact 2-column table (period, rate), never exceeding 4 rows. No percentage-based explanations ('15% seasonal increase') -- only absolute dollar figures.
scan_order: Rate range: '$280-$301/night' as a single compound figure (System 1: 'This is roughly what it costs', under 2 seconds)
Rate period labels: 'Oct-Dec: $280' and 'Jan-Feb: $301' (System 2: 'When does each rate apply?', 2-4 seconds)
Total cost derived from blended rates (System 2: 'What's my actual total?', 4-6 seconds)
Explanation of seasonal logic (System 2: only if the guest wants to understand why, 6+ seconds, on demand)
exclude: A single nightly rate that hides seasonal variation. If the lease spans rate boundaries, the guest must see the range.
Seasonal pricing disclosed only in terms and conditions, FAQ, or fine print. The rate range must appear in the same visual context as the primary rate display.
Percentage-based seasonal adjustments ('rates increase 8% in winter'). Show absolute dollars per night.
Rate changes disclosed for the first time at the Date Change screen during active_lease. By then, the guest has anchored on the original rate and any increase feels like a penalty.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Pre-commitment rate anchoring -- showing seasonal rate variability before the guest locks a single rate in memory. Extends the library's single-sum principle to account for multi-season leases where a single rate is misleading.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Nneka's seasonal pricing revelation ($1,170 to higher rates) directly evidences the anchoring trap. Kahneman's anchoring and Muller-Lyer illusion research provides strong theoretical support.

elements.title: Date Change Request as a Three-Tap Contextual Flow, Not a Separate Page
elements.problem: Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because the platform offers no faster alternative. The interaction pattern for date changes must compete with the speed and simplicity of a text message: 'Hey, can I switch Thursday for Tuesday?' takes about 10 seconds to type. Any platform flow that exceeds this cognitive and temporal cost will lose to texting. The current Date Change section presents a 'Request Changes' button that leads to a form with change types, pricing rules, and a submission process -- a multi-step System 2 workflow that a depleted hybrid worker will abandon in favor of a 10-second text. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts that the guest will always choose the path requiring the least cognitive investment. If that path is texting, the platform never captures the interaction, cannot enforce pricing rules, and loses visibility into the guest's schedule behavior.
elements.solution: Embed the date change initiation directly within each stay row (or the hero card) so the guest never leaves the Stays Manager. The interaction is three taps: (1) Tap the specific stay or a 'Change' affordance on the hero card. A bottom sheet or inline expansion opens, showing the three change types (Swap, Add, Remove) as tappable cards with financial consequences pre-computed and visible. (2) Tap the desired change type. The view updates to show available alternative dates (pulled from synced host availability in real time), each with its cost delta. Unavailable dates are not shown at all -- the guest never selects a date that will be rejected. (3) Tap the desired date and confirm. The request is submitted, the host is notified, and the stay row updates to show 'Change pending' status. Total interaction time target: under 30 seconds. The key interaction principle: the change flow is contextual (it knows which stay the guest is changing), pre-computed (financial consequences are calculated before the guest sees options), and constrained (only available dates are shown). This eliminates the three System 2 tasks that make forms slow: identifying what to change, computing the cost, and guessing which dates will work.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad's rescheduling vocabulary is exactly three elements: which night he cannot make, a request for a different night, and a conditional on availability. The platform flow must capture these same three elements in three taps, not in a multi-field form.

evidence.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to... it would be a different rate.
evidence.insight: The distinction between replace and add has financial consequences the guest may not anticipate. The interaction pattern must present both options with their costs visible at the same time, so the guest makes an informed choice in a single comparison rather than discovering the cost difference after selecting.

evidence.quote: A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
evidence.insight: Texting is the current least-effort path. The platform must become the new least-effort path by reducing taps, eliminating form fields, pre-computing costs, and showing only viable options. Every field the guest must fill, every option they must evaluate, and every date they must guess at pushes them back toward the text message.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 409-438
evidence.quote: Request Changes button - Initiate modification. Accept/Reject incoming requests. Remove expired requests. Flexibility Score displayed as percentage.
evidence.insight: The current design separates the change initiation (Request Changes button) from the change context (which stay is being changed). The guest clicks a generic button and then must specify the stay. The interaction pattern reverses this: the stay is the entry point, and the change options are contextual to that stay.

states.default: Each stay row shows a subtle 'Change' affordance (icon or text link) visible on hover/focus or always-visible on mobile. The hero card for the current week shows the affordance prominently. No separate 'Request Changes' button needed -- changes originate from specific stays.
states.loading: When the change bottom sheet opens, available dates load with a compact skeleton (date chips with pulse animation) that shows the layout shape while availability data loads. Change type cards appear instantly (they require no server data). The split load ensures the guest sees actionable options within 200ms even if availability takes 500ms.
states.empty: If no alternative dates are available for the selected change type (host has no availability), the bottom sheet shows: 'No available dates for this change. Your host's calendar is full for [date range].' with a 'Message host' fallback action. No dead-end empty state.
states.error: If availability data fails to load, the date chips area shows: 'Could not check availability. [Retry] or [Message host].' The change type cards remain visible so the guest can still see the options and their costs even if date selection is temporarily unavailable.
states.success: On submission, the bottom sheet collapses with a downward slide animation, and the stay row updates its status badge to 'Change pending' (amber badge per looks-004). A brief inline confirmation appears on the stay row: 'Request sent to host' that fades after 3 seconds. No full-screen success state that takes the guest away from the Stays Manager.

elements.transition_principle: The bottom sheet rises from the bottom of the viewport with the tokens.json spring easing, creating a physical feeling of a drawer opening. Each subsequent tap within the flow (selecting change type, selecting date) triggers a lateral crossfade of the content area within the sheet -- the sheet itself never closes and reopens. The back action within the sheet returns to the previous step with a reverse crossfade. Confirmation dismisses the sheet with a faster downward slide (150ms) than the opening (250ms), creating a satisfying 'done' feeling that is quicker than the exploratory opening.

timing.response_target: 200ms for bottom sheet open, 150ms for step transitions within sheet, 150ms for sheet dismiss on confirmation, 500ms maximum for availability data load
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1) for sheet open (spring), cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1) for content transitions and sheet close (out)
timing.rationale: The spring easing (0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1) from tokens.json gives the bottom sheet a slight overshoot on open, creating a playful physical quality that signals 'this is interactive, not a static page.' The out easing (0.16, 1, 0.3, 1) for content transitions and close provides smooth deceleration. The asymmetry between open (250ms, spring) and close (150ms, out) reflects the psychological difference: opening is exploratory (slower, with overshoot), closing is decisive (faster, no overshoot).

elements.journey_state_awareness: Early in the lease (Weeks 1-3): date change affordance is subtle (icon only) because the guest is still learning the Stays Manager. Mid-lease (Weeks 4-10): affordance becomes more visible if the guest has not yet used it (a one-time tooltip: 'Need to change a date? Tap here'). Late lease (Weeks 11-13): affordance remains but the system preemptively notes 'Limited availability remaining' if the host's calendar is filling up. If the guest has previously completed a date change, the flow skips any instructional framing on subsequent uses.
edge_cases: Guest attempts to change a date that is less than 24 hours away: the flow shows a warning inline ('This stay starts tomorrow. Changes may not be processed in time. [Proceed anyway] or [Message host directly]') rather than blocking the action.

Host has auto-accept enabled for certain change types: the flow shows 'Instant approval' badge on the change type card, and on submission the status immediately shows 'Confirmed' rather than 'Pending.'

Guest has a low Flexibility Score: the flow proceeds normally. The Flexibility Score is visible as context but never blocks or delays the change request. The guest should never feel penalized for using the tool.

Multiple date changes pending for the same week: the system shows a stacked indicator ('2 changes pending for this week') and allows viewing each pending change, but blocks a new change for the same dates until the prior one resolves.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Three-tap contextual date change flow that competes with text messaging speed. No existing library element addresses interaction patterns for in-lease schedule management. This fills the behavioral gap for the guest's most frequent action during active_lease.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Brad's texting behavior (nneka-call.txt, 01:23-01:42) directly evidences the need. Kahneman's law of least effort provides the benchmark: the platform flow must be faster than composing a text message.

elements.title: Notification-Driven Re-Engagement: Pull the Guest Back Only When Something Changed
elements.problem: The guest has no reason to visit the platform unless something requires their attention. During active_lease, the weekly visit pattern exists because the guest needs to check their stay status. But during negotiation (waiting for a host response) and between payment cycles, the guest has no trigger to return. Brad texts Nneka because there is no notification system telling him what happened with his request. Bryant explicitly describes the missing notification infrastructure: 'We will be working on basically just having a way to notify you. So you will know when a request comes in' (08:40-09:07). Without notifications, the guest must actively check the platform for updates -- a polling behavior that is effortful, anxiety-producing, and unsustainable. Kahneman's ego depletion research predicts that the guest will stop polling after a few fruitless checks, and then miss important updates when they finally arrive.
elements.solution: Implement a notification system that is the primary driver of guest re-engagement during waiting states. The system operates on one rule: notify when action is needed or a status changed, never for marketing or engagement farming. Notification types: (1) 'Host responded to your proposal' -- links directly to the counter-offer view. (2) 'Date change approved/declined' -- links to the updated stay in the Stays Manager. (3) 'Payment processed' -- links to the receipt in the Payment Schedule. (4) 'Upcoming payment in 3 days' -- links to the payment method confirmation. (5) 'Review available' -- links to the batched review card at the milestone. Each notification is a single sentence that tells the guest what happened and what (if anything) they need to do. Tapping the notification deep-links to the exact context: not the dashboard, not the leases list, but the specific stay, payment, or proposal stage that changed. The deep-link ensures the guest's System 2 is immediately engaged with the relevant content, not wasted on navigation. The interaction pattern for notifications is: one sentence, one action, one destination. No notification leads to a page that requires further navigation to find the relevant content.

evidence.quote: We'll be working on basically just having a way to notify you. So you'll know when a request comes in and then from there you'd be able to either accept the request.
evidence.insight: Bryant describes notifications as a core missing feature, not a nice-to-have. The current system has no way to tell the guest that something happened. This forces the guest into manual polling or off-platform communication, both of which are cognitively expensive.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day.
evidence.insight: Texting is Brad's notification system. He texts because no push notification told him whether his previous request was handled. If a push notification had said 'Your date change was approved -- Oct 15 swapped for Oct 22,' he would have no reason to text.

evidence.quote: System 2 is mobilized when a question arises for which System 1 does not offer an answer.
evidence.insight: The question 'Did the host see my proposal?' has no System 1 answer because the platform provides no signal. System 2 remains mobilized to monitor this unanswered question. A notification that says 'Your host viewed your proposal 2 hours ago' answers the question and releases System 2.

evidence.quote: The often-used phrase 'pay attention' is apt: you dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities.
evidence.insight: Every manual platform check ('let me see if the host responded') costs attention from the guest's limited budget. Notifications invert this cost: the platform spends compute to save the guest attention. This is the correct trade-off for a platform serving depleted hybrid workers.

states.default: No notification badge or indicator when nothing has changed. The absence of notifications is itself a positive signal: 'Everything is on track, nothing needs your attention.' The platform does not create artificial urgency.
states.loading: Not applicable to notifications themselves. When the guest taps a notification and the deep-linked content loads, the destination page loads with a highlighted state on the relevant element (a brief golden outline or background flash that fades after 2 seconds) so the guest immediately sees what changed.
states.empty: If the guest opens a notification center or in-app notification list and has no notifications: 'All caught up. We will notify you when something needs your attention.' This is an affirmative empty state, not a void.
states.error: If a notification deep-link fails (the referenced proposal was withdrawn, the payment was reversed): the destination page shows the current state with a note: 'This notification referred to [event] which has since been updated. Here is the current status.' No broken link dead-end.
states.success: Notification tapped and action completed (e.g., guest accepts counter-offer from notification): the notification is marked as resolved, and a brief inline confirmation replaces the notification content: 'Done -- counter-offer accepted.' The notification list shows a checkmark on resolved items.

elements.transition_principle: Notifications arrive silently during non-active use (the guest's phone vibrates or shows a standard push notification). When the guest returns to the app from a notification, the transition to the deep-linked content uses a special entrance animation: the relevant element (a proposal stage, a stay row, a payment summary) briefly highlights with a warm glow (accent-light background that fades over 2 seconds) to guide the eye directly to what changed. This highlight is the only animation -- the rest of the page loads normally. The highlight answers the question 'what is different since my last visit?' without requiring the guest to scan the entire page.

timing.response_target: Push notification delivery: within 60 seconds of status change. Deep-link page load: under 1 second. Highlight animation on relevant element: 2 second fade from accent-light (#e8f0eb) to transparent.
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1) for highlight fade
timing.rationale: The 2-second highlight fade using out easing provides a gentle, warm indication of change that does not feel like an alarm. The accent-light green (#e8f0eb) from tokens.json is chosen because it is the platform's trust color, signaling 'something good happened here' rather than 'danger.' The 60-second notification delivery window balances real-time urgency with infrastructure practicality.

elements.journey_state_awareness: During negotiation: notifications are frequent and high-priority (host responded, counter-offer received, proposal accepted). The guest expects these and the notification system delivers them within 60 seconds. During active_lease: notifications are infrequent and routine (payment processed, review milestone, date change resolved). The guest has settled into a weekly rhythm and notifications serve as gentle supplements, not primary drivers. Post-lease: notifications reduce to zero except for final review prompt and deposit return status. The notification cadence mirrors the emotional intensity of each journey phase.
edge_cases: Guest has notifications disabled at the OS level: the in-app notification center becomes the primary status channel. A subtle badge on the app icon (if supported) or an in-app banner on next visit communicates unread updates.

Multiple status changes occur between guest visits (e.g., host countered, then withdrew counter, then re-countered): notifications are coalesced into the most recent state rather than showing a confusing sequence. The guest sees 'Host updated their offer' not three separate notifications.

Guest receives a notification during a different app session (e.g., while in the Stays Manager): the notification appears as an in-app banner at the top of the screen that slides down (200ms, out easing) and auto-dismisses after 5 seconds unless tapped.
Notification references a lease the guest is no longer active on (post-lease deposit return): the notification links to a post-lease summary view, not to the now-inactive Stays Manager.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Notification-driven re-engagement system for guest journey. Extends the library's notification-as-continuation principle (behaves-006) to the guest side, with specific implementation patterns for deep-linking, coalescing, and contextual highlighting on arrival.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Bryant explicitly confirms notifications are missing and being built (08:40-09:07). Brad's texting behavior is direct evidence of the gap notifications would fill.

elements.title: The Text Message Temptation: Making the Platform Feel Easier Than Informal Channels
elements.problem: Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because texting is the path of least emotional resistance. A text message feels personal, immediate, and low-commitment: 'Hey, can I switch Thursday for Tuesday?' takes 10 seconds and creates no formal record. The platform, by contrast, feels official, slow, and consequential: filling out a form, clicking submit, waiting for a system response. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts that the guest will always choose the cognitively easier path. But the emotional dimension is equally important: texting feels human and casual; the platform feels institutional and formal. The guest is not just choosing the easier path -- they are choosing the path that feels less like doing paperwork and more like talking to a person. This emotional preference for informality over formality is particularly strong for the target persona (hybrid workers managing demanding jobs) who spend their workdays in formal systems and crave informality in their personal logistics. The platform currently offers no emotional counterweight to this preference: it looks and feels like a management console, not a conversation.
elements.solution: Design every guest-initiated interaction during active_lease to feel conversational rather than administrative. The date change flow should feel like sending a message, not filing a request. The copy should mirror the casual language of a text message: 'Swap Thu for Tue?' rather than 'Submit Date Change Request.' The response from the system should feel like a reply: 'Got it. Sent to Nneka. She usually responds within a day.' The emotional principle is: the platform must feel like a smarter version of the text thread, not a replacement for it. The guest should think 'I could text Nneka, but the platform is just as easy and keeps track of everything.' This means: (1) Input speed must match texting speed -- three taps, not three form fields. (2) Language must match texting casualness -- first names, short sentences, no jargon. (3) Feedback must match texting immediacy -- instant acknowledgment, not 'your request has been submitted.' (4) The emotional reward of using the platform must exceed texting: the guest sees available dates (no guessing), sees the cost impact (no surprises), and has a record (no 'did I already text her about Tuesday?').

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: The emotional texture of Brad's rescheduling is casual human conversation: 'Hey, I can't make it, can I do another day?' The platform must match this emotional texture while adding the structural benefits (availability checking, pricing calculation, record keeping) that texting lacks.

evidence.quote: A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
evidence.insight: The least demanding path is emotional as well as cognitive. Texting feels easy because it is informal. A platform form feels hard because it is formal. The platform must reduce both cognitive load (fewer taps) and emotional load (casual tone) to compete with texting.

elements.emotion_rationale: Ease is the feeling that the platform is not work. The hybrid worker already spends 8+ hours per day in formal, cognitively demanding systems. When they manage their housing, they want the interaction to feel effortless and casual -- like texting a friend, not like using enterprise software. Ease is what converts 'I have to check the platform' into 'I will just check the platform.' The emotional distance between obligation and choice is the definition of ease.

do: Use first names: 'Sent to Nneka' not 'Sent to your host'
Use contractions and short sentences: 'Got it. She usually responds in a day.'
Mirror the language a friend would use: 'Swap Thu for Tue?' not 'Replace scheduled date with alternative date'
Confirm actions with conversational acknowledgments: 'Done' or 'Sent' rather than 'Your request has been successfully submitted'
dont: Use formal request language: 'Submit Date Change Request' sounds like filing a form, not managing your week
Use platform jargon: 'Initiate modification' or 'Process rescheduling' are internal terms that create emotional distance
Add unnecessary confirmations: 'Are you sure you want to proceed?' for a simple date swap creates anxiety where none should exist
Use passive voice: 'Your request has been submitted' distances the guest from their action. 'Sent to Nneka' connects them to the human on the other end.
copy_guidelines.example_good: Swap Oct 15 for Oct 22? Same rate. [Send to Nneka]
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Date Change Request: Replace October 15, 2025 with October 22, 2025. Rate adjustment: $0.00. [Submit Request]

animation_feel.feel_description: A message-send bounce. When the guest confirms a date change or action, the confirmation animates with a slight spring overshoot -- the same physics a chat bubble uses when it appears in a messaging app. The sensation is 'message sent' not 'form submitted.' The spring easing creates a playful, lightweight feeling that contrasts with the rigid, weightless feel of traditional form submissions. On the receiving end, when the host responds, the response appears with the same spring -- creating a conversational rhythm that feels like a text thread.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-250ms for the send animation with spring overshoot

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest needs to change a date and is deciding whether to text the host or use the platform.
tension_relief.relief_point: The platform flow is faster, easier, and more informative than a text message. The guest sees available dates (no guessing), sees the cost (no surprises), and completes the change in three taps (faster than composing a text).
tension_relief.timing: The relief window is narrow: the guest must reach the date change flow and see its simplicity within 10 seconds of deciding to make a change. If the flow takes longer to initiate than opening the text app, the guest will choose texting.

personalization_signals: Use the host's first name in all confirmations and status updates
Reference specific dates and nights, not abstract time ranges
If the guest has a pattern (always swaps Thursdays), preemptively suggest: 'Swap this Thursday too?'
Show the host's response pattern: 'Nneka usually responds in a few hours' to set casual expectations

anti_patterns.pattern: Using formal, bureaucratic language for routine active-lease interactions
anti_patterns.reason: Formal language creates emotional distance between the guest and the platform. The guest is managing their weekly living arrangement, not filing a legal claim. Bureaucratic copy ('Your Date Change Request has been submitted for review') makes the platform feel like an institution the guest must comply with rather than a tool that serves them.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Date Modification Request #4827 has been submitted. The host will be notified. Please allow 48 hours for processing.

coherence_note.gap_filled: The text message temptation -- making the platform feel emotionally easier than informal channels. No existing library element addresses the emotional competition between formal platform tools and informal text messaging. This fills a gap in the active_lease emotional architecture specific to the guest persona.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Brad's texting preference (01:23-01:42) is direct behavioral evidence. Kahneman's law of least effort applies to emotional load as well as cognitive load -- the insight that 'casual' feels easier than 'formal' is well-grounded.

elements.title: The Discovery Promise: Setting Honest Expectations That Survive Contact With Reality
elements.problem: Kahneman's priming and associative coherence research demonstrates that the first encounter with a brand activates an associative network that shapes interpretation of every subsequent interaction. If the guest's first encounter with Split Lease primes 'flexible, easy housing,' then every friction point -- rescheduling complexity, pricing confusion, availability constraints -- contradicts the primed network and triggers cognitive dissonance. The Nneka call reveals exactly this disconnect: the platform promises flexibility, but Brad's actual experience of rescheduling involves texting the host, waiting for manual availability checks, and discovering that dates cost more than expected. The emotional damage is not caused by the friction itself -- every platform has friction. It is caused by the gap between what was promised at discovery and what is delivered during the lease. This is Kahneman's violation model: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The discovery touchpoint builds the model. The active lease tests it.
elements.solution: Design discovery messaging that honestly prepares the guest for the reality of mid-term housing negotiation. Instead of promising 'easy flexibility,' promise 'transparent flexibility': 'Find mid-term housing with clear pricing, real-time availability, and a rescheduling tool that shows you exactly what changes cost before you commit.' This sets an expectation that is specific enough to be tested and honest enough to survive contact with reality. The emotional principle is: under-promise on ease, over-deliver on transparency. The guest who expects 'transparent flexibility' and encounters a rate comparison display feels the platform delivered on its promise. The guest who expects 'easy flexibility' and encounters any friction at all feels deceived. At search and listing evaluation, continue the honesty: show schedule compatibility upfront (not after the guest invests evaluation effort), show rate ranges when dates span seasons (not single misleading rates), and show 'proposal-based booking' clearly (not 'book now' language that implies instant booking). Every discovery touchpoint should set an expectation that the Stays Manager can fulfill 13 weeks later.

evidence.quote: Ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity in your brain... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
evidence.insight: Whatever the guest encounters at discovery primes an entire associative network. If 'Split Lease' is first associated with 'instant' and 'easy,' every subsequent friction (proposal waiting, rescheduling negotiation) contradicts the primed network. If the first association is 'transparent' and 'fair,' friction is expected and tolerable.

evidence.quote: Brad and I had our contract ended in January or February... it's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Brad's experience reveals that mid-term housing inherently involves rescheduling and pricing variability. Discovery messaging that hides this reality sets up the guest for disappointment. Discovery messaging that frames it as a managed, transparent feature sets the guest up for realistic expectations that the platform can meet.

elements.emotion_rationale: Trust at discovery is the foundation for every subsequent emotional interaction. A guest who trusts the platform's honesty at discovery will interpret mid-lease friction as 'the platform warned me about this.' A guest who feels misled at discovery will interpret the same friction as 'they lied to me.' Trust is not built by promising a perfect experience -- it is built by accurately describing the real one. The guest who was told 'flexibility with transparency' and encounters transparent pricing controls feels trust confirmed. The guest who was told 'easy, flexible housing' and encounters any complexity feels trust violated.

do: Name the reality: 'Mid-term housing with proposal-based booking' not 'Book your perfect space now'
Describe the actual flow: 'Find a space, submit a proposal, negotiate terms, move in' not 'Find and book instantly'
Lead with the differentiator: 'See what rescheduling costs before you commit' is specific and testable
Use language at discovery that the Stays Manager will echo: if discovery says 'transparent pricing,' the Stays Manager should show rate comparisons
dont: Promise ease when the actual flow involves negotiation: 'Easy, flexible housing' sets an expectation that any friction violates
Use Airbnb-style instant-booking language when the model is proposal-based: 'Book now' on a proposal flow is a lie of omission
Hide the negotiation aspect: the proposal-counter-accept flow is the core product, not a bug. Present it as a feature.
Promise flexibility without qualification: 'Flexibility' means different things to different people. Specify: 'Reschedule dates with real-time availability and upfront pricing'
copy_guidelines.example_good: Mid-term housing that adapts to your schedule. See available dates, know the cost of changes, and manage your stay in one place.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Find flexible housing in seconds. Book your perfect space and move in hassle-free.

animation_feel.feel_description: A grounded entry. Discovery page elements load with a subtle upward movement (8px translate) and fade-in, creating a sense of solidity and substance. Nothing bounces, springs, or overshoots -- the landing page feels planted and confident, like a handshake rather than a wave. The sensation is 'this is a real product, not a marketing illusion.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 300-400ms for initial page element entrances, staggered by 50ms per element

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest is evaluating whether Split Lease is legitimate and whether its promises will hold up during an actual lease.
tension_relief.relief_point: Discovery copy names the actual process (proposals, negotiation, rescheduling with pricing) rather than hiding it behind marketing abstraction. The guest thinks 'they are telling me how it really works, not just how they want me to think it works.'
tension_relief.timing: Trust must form in the first 10 seconds of the discovery page. If the guest's System 1 labels the platform as 'too good to be true' or 'another Airbnb clone,' that impression is extremely difficult to reverse. Honest, specific language in the first 10 seconds prevents these labels from forming.

personalization_signals: If the guest arrived via a specific search query (e.g., 'midterm housing NYC weeknights'), echo that context on the landing page
Show real listing examples relevant to the guest's apparent need, not generic showcase properties
If referral data is available, reference it: 'Your friend [name] uses Split Lease for weeknight stays in [city]'
Surface the guest persona explicitly: 'Designed for hybrid workers who need a place during the work week'
