elements.title: Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points, Not Per-Stay Interruptions
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. Over a 13-week lease, this creates 13 review prompts that accumulate as an unfinished to-do list visible on every visit. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that sequential self-control tasks drain from a shared pool: the first review is thoughtful, but by Week 5, the guest's System 2 has been depleted by four prior reviews plus their work responsibilities. The interaction problem is not just fatigue -- it is that the accumulating unreviewd stays create a guilt signal on every visit. The Stays Manager, which should feel like a helpful dashboard, starts to feel like a nagging task list. The guest who ignores 5 review buttons feels irresponsible; the guest who dutifully completes them feels drained. Neither outcome serves the guest or the platform. The interaction pattern must collect high-quality feedback without converting the Stays Manager into an obligation.
elements.solution: Replace per-stay review buttons with three batched review moments at natural lease milestones: after Week 4 (first payment cycle), at the lease midpoint, and after the final stay. Each review moment appears as a highlighted card in the hero position of the Stays Manager, gently displacing the weekly status card for one visit. The review card includes pre-filled context (the weeks covered, the property name, a sentence summarizing the period) and asks for a single overall rating plus one optional text field. The interaction is: see the card, tap a rating, optionally type a sentence, submit. Under 90 seconds. Between review moments, completed stays show a muted 'Reviewed' or 'Review at Week [N]' label rather than active 'Review' buttons. The key interaction principle: the review card appears once at each milestone, and if dismissed without completion, it moves to a secondary position (below the hero card) for the next 2 visits, then disappears entirely. The platform does not nag. Three thoughtful reviews at reflection points yield richer data than thirteen perfunctory star ratings.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 453-459
evidence.quote: After each stay: 'Review' button becomes active. Guest rates property/host. Rates on: Cleanliness, accuracy, communication. Writes text review (optional).
evidence.insight: 13 active Review buttons over 13 weeks creates an accumulating to-do list. Each unreviewd stay is a small guilt signal. The interaction pattern must eliminate this accumulation by collecting feedback at defined intervals rather than after every single stay.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: Each review is a self-control task: recall the week, evaluate three dimensions, compose optional text. The depletion from one review reduces the likelihood and quality of the next. Batching to three review moments respects the depletion curve: the guest gives feedback when they have something meaningful to reflect on, not when the system's per-week data structure demands it.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a working professional. Their cognitive budget for platform administration is minimal. The interaction pattern must treat review as a secondary activity that fits into the guest's existing weekly visit pattern, not as a primary obligation that demands a separate session.

evidence.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
evidence.insight: Kahneman advocates dividing tasks into easy steps, but the current design over-divides: 13 micro-reviews are individually easy but collectively overwhelming. The batched approach consolidates to 3 meaningful reflection moments that are richer and lighter.

states.default: Between review milestones: no review prompts visible. Completed stays show a small 'Reviewed' chip or 'Review at Week [N]' note in muted text. The Stays Manager is a clean status dashboard, not a task list.
states.loading: Review card skeleton renders in the hero position with a star rating placeholder and text field outline. The skeleton establishes that a review is being requested before the context data loads, giving the guest a moment to prepare mentally.
states.empty: If the review milestone is reached but no stays are completed (unlikely edge case): the review card does not appear. Reviews are only prompted when there is something to review. No 'You have no stays to review' empty state.
states.error: If review submission fails, the review card shows an inline error: 'Could not save your review. [Try again].' The guest's rating and text input are preserved so they do not need to re-enter. The card does not disappear on error.
states.success: On submission, the review card plays a brief thank-you animation: the star rating pulses once, a checkmark appears, and the card shrinks smoothly (300ms, out easing) to reveal the hero card beneath. A small toast appears: 'Thank you for your feedback.' No full-page celebration that feels disproportionate to a review submission.

elements.transition_principle: The review card enters from above (sliding down into hero position, 250ms, out easing) on the first visit after a milestone, displacing the weekly hero card downward. This spatial relationship communicates that the review is temporarily more important than the weekly status, but the weekly status is still present below. When the review is submitted or dismissed, it exits upward (sliding up, 200ms, out easing) and the hero card slides back up to its default position. The movement metaphor is: the review card is a brief visitor in the hero position, not a permanent resident.

timing.response_target: Review card appearance: 250ms slide-in on page load at milestone visit. Star rating tap response: immediate (<50ms). Review submission: 500ms maximum server response. Success animation: 300ms. Card exit: 200ms.
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)
timing.rationale: The out easing for the review card's entrance and exit creates a smooth, non-jarring insertion into the page flow. The 250ms entrance is slow enough to be noticed (the guest should see the review card arrive) but fast enough to not feel like a loading delay. The 200ms exit is faster than the entrance because dismissal should feel swift and decisive.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Week 4 review: framed as 'first impressions' ('How were your first 4 weeks at [property]?'). Midpoint review: framed as 'settled-in assessment' ('You are halfway through. How is the space working for your routine?'). Final review: framed as 'overall experience' ('Your lease at [property] has ended. How was the experience overall?'). Each framing gives the guest a cognitive anchor for their reflection, reducing the effort of generating a response from scratch.
edge_cases: Guest dismisses the Week 4 review card: it moves to secondary position (below hero card) for 2 visits, then disappears. If still unreviewed by midpoint, the midpoint review covers Weeks 1 through midpoint instead of just the recent period.
Guest's lease is shorter than 8 weeks (no midpoint): only two review moments -- after Week 4 and after the final stay.

Guest wants to review a specific week in detail: an 'Add details for a specific week' expand option within the batched review card lets the guest drill into individual weeks. This is opt-in, never required.

Guest submits a very negative review: the review card does not immediately close. It shows a follow-up prompt: 'Would you like to report a specific issue? [Report issue]' -- connecting the review to the action system rather than leaving negative feedback as a dead end.

elements.title: The Waiting Ache: Resolving Proposal Anxiety Through Status Visibility
elements.problem: After submitting a proposal, the guest enters an emotionally vulnerable state: they have committed to wanting a place to stay, but they do not know if they will get it. Kahneman describes how System 2 is activated when 'an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The guest's model after submission is 'I acted, something should happen.' When the platform shows no change -- no acknowledgment, no timeline, no indication that the host has seen the proposal -- System 2 stays activated in monitoring mode. This is not a one-time activation; it is a persistent, low-grade cognitive drain that competes with the guest's work responsibilities. Brad's behavior confirms this pattern: he texts Nneka directly because the platform provides no channel for resolving the uncertainty. The emotional cost of this opacity is not just anxiety -- it is helplessness. The guest cannot do anything to accelerate the process, cannot see whether progress is happening, and cannot plan their housing situation. Helplessness is the most disempowering emotion a platform can inflict, and it is entirely created by the absence of status information.
elements.solution: Replace helplessness with informed patience. At every stage of the proposal pipeline, provide three pieces of emotional infrastructure: (1) Acknowledgment: 'Your proposal was received and sent to [host name].' This validates the guest's action. (2) Timeline: 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours. Submitted 14 hours ago.' This converts open-ended uncertainty into bounded waiting. (3) Agency: 'If you do not hear back by [date], you can send a reminder or contact support.' This gives the guest a future action to hold onto, preventing the feeling that they are entirely at the mercy of the host. The emotional principle is: the guest can tolerate waiting if they know what they are waiting for, how long it should take, and what they can do if it takes too long. Open-ended, information-free waiting is emotionally intolerable. Bounded, transparent waiting is manageable.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad texts because the platform provides no status channel. The emotional driver is not impatience -- it is the inability to tolerate uncertainty without any information. A status display that says 'waiting on host, expected response within 48 hours' would reduce the emotional urgency of the text.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model after submission is 'something should happen next.' When nothing visibly happens, System 2 activates to monitor the gap. This activation is emotionally experienced as anxiety -- the cognitive strain of unresolved uncertainty. Status updates resolve the gap by confirming that the process is proceeding even when the guest cannot see it.

elements.emotion_rationale: Assurance is the opposite of helplessness. The guest who feels assured knows that the process is working, knows when to expect a result, and knows what they can do if the result does not arrive. Assurance does not require certainty of outcome -- it requires certainty of process. A guest can be assured that 'hosts typically respond within 48 hours' even though they do not know what the response will be.

do: Name the person the guest is waiting on: 'Waiting on [host name]' not 'Waiting on host response'
Provide specific time context: 'Submitted 14 hours ago' and 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours'
Offer a future action: 'No response by Friday? You can send a reminder.'
Acknowledge the guest's emotional state implicitly: 'We will notify you the moment [host name] responds' -- the promise of notification is itself reassuring
dont: Use vague status language: 'Processing' without a timeline is anxiety, not information
Over-reassure: 'Do not worry! Your host will get back to you soon!' -- this patronizes the guest and provides no useful information
Hide the elapsed time: showing 'Submitted 14 hours ago' is more comforting than hiding the clock, because it proves the system is tracking
Make the guest feel they must monitor: 'Check back soon for updates' creates an obligation to poll, which is the opposite of assurance
copy_guidelines.example_good: Waiting on Nneka. Submitted 14h ago. Hosts typically respond within 48h. We will notify you when she responds.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Your proposal is being reviewed. Please check back later for updates.

animation_feel.feel_description: A patient pulse. During waiting states, the current pipeline stage uses a very slow, barely perceptible breathing animation on the action assignment tag (opacity oscillates between 0.8 and 1.0 over 3 seconds). This communicates 'the system is alive and watching' without creating urgency. The sensation is like seeing the steady blink of a charging indicator -- it confirms activity without demanding attention. When the status changes (host responds), the breathing stops and the stage transition animation plays, creating a crisp contrast between waiting and progress.
animation_feel.duration_range: 3000ms breathing cycle during waiting states; 300-400ms for stage transition animations

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest submitted a proposal or date change request and does not know if it was seen, is being reviewed, or was forgotten.
tension_relief.relief_point: The pipeline shows exactly who must act, how long ago the request was sent, and what the expected response time is. A push notification confirms the moment the host responds.
tension_relief.timing: Partial relief is immediate (status display on submission). Full relief arrives when the host responds (push notification + pipeline update). The design must provide enough partial relief that the guest does not feel compelled to text the host or check the platform repeatedly.

personalization_signals: Use the host's actual name in status messages: 'Waiting on Nneka' not 'Waiting on host'
Show the host's typical response time if data is available: 'Nneka usually responds within 12 hours'
After the first proposal, subsequent proposals skip instructional text and show just the status
If the guest has previously experienced a fast host response, set expectations accordingly: 'Nneka responded to your last request in 6 hours'

anti_patterns.pattern: A waiting state with no timeline, no action assignment, and no future agency
anti_patterns.reason: Open-ended, information-free waiting triggers helplessness -- the most disempowering emotion in a platform experience. The guest cannot plan, cannot act, and cannot even estimate when they will be able to plan or act. This is the emotional state that drives off-platform workarounds (texting the host) and eventually platform abandonment.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your proposal is under review. We will let you know when there is an update.

elements.title: The Administrative Guilt Accumulator: Transforming Obligation Into Reflection
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. Over 13 weeks, unreviewed stays accumulate as a visible to-do list on the page the guest visits weekly. Each unreviewed stay is a small guilt signal: the platform is silently asking 'Why have you not reviewed Week 3 yet?' while the guest is just trying to check their current week status. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that the guilt from unfinished tasks draws from the same System 2 pool as the tasks themselves -- meaning the guilt is cognitively depleting even when the guest does not act on it. The emotional trajectory is: Week 1-3, the guest dutifully reviews each stay. Week 4-6, reviews become perfunctory (5 stars, no text). Week 7+, the guest stops reviewing but sees the accumulating 'Review' buttons on every visit, creating a background hum of guilt that makes the Stays Manager feel like a nagging parent rather than a helpful dashboard. By Week 13, the guest's emotional association with the Stays Manager is 'the page that makes me feel behind' rather than 'the page that helps me manage my stay.' This emotional contamination damages the guest's entire relationship with the platform.
elements.solution: Eliminate the guilt accumulator by replacing per-stay review buttons with three batched review moments at natural reflection points (Week 4, midpoint, final). Between review moments, the Stays Manager shows no review prompts at all. Completed stays display 'Reviewed' or remain quietly unmarked -- never an active 'Review' button that the guest must consciously choose to ignore. When a batched review moment arrives, it appears as a warm invitation, not an obligation: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' rather than 'Rate your stay for Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, and Week 4.' The emotional reframe is: reviewing is a moment of reflection offered at the right time, not an ongoing obligation imposed by the platform's data structure. The guest should feel 'Oh, time to reflect on how this is going' (pleasant) not 'Oh, I still have not reviewed five stays' (guilt).

evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: The guilt of unreviewed stays is itself a form of ego depletion. Each time the guest sees a 'Review' button and decides not to act, they exert self-control (resisting the guilt). This depletion accumulates over weeks, making the Stays Manager feel increasingly burdensome even when the guest is not reviewing.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a busy professional. Administrative guilt from a housing platform competes with professional obligations for the same depleted cognitive resources. A platform that makes the guest feel 'behind' on reviews while they are already behind on work emails creates an emotional association that discourages return visits.

elements.emotion_rationale: Lightness is the absence of unnecessary weight. The Stays Manager should feel like a surface the guest bounces off of quickly -- check status, see nothing needs attention, leave. Accumulated review obligations add weight that slows each visit and darkens the emotional tone. Lightness is achieved by removing the weight: no visible obligations, no guilt signals, no accumulating to-do list. The guest feels light when the platform asks nothing of them on most visits and offers a natural reflection moment on a few.

do: Frame reviews as reflection: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' invites thought rather than demanding compliance
Acknowledge that reviews are optional in the framing: 'If you have a moment' or 'When you are ready'
Pre-fill context so the guest does not have to recall specifics: 'Your stays covered Oct 1-25 at [property]'
After submission, thank briefly and naturally: 'Thanks. Your feedback helps [host name] improve.'
dont: Show accumulating 'Review' buttons on completed stays -- this is the single biggest emotional anti-pattern in the Stays Manager
Use obligation language: 'You have 5 unreviewed stays' or 'Please review your recent stays'
Send reminder emails or notifications about pending reviews -- this extends the guilt off-platform
Make the review a blocking condition for anything: 'Complete your review to access [feature]'
copy_guidelines.example_good: You have been at [property] for 4 weeks now. Got a minute to share how it is going?
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You have 4 unreviewed stays. Please rate your experience for: Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, Week 4.

animation_feel.feel_description: A gentle arrival. The batched review card slides down into the hero position from above with a slow, gravity-like ease -- it descends into view like a note being placed on a table, not like a notification demanding attention. If dismissed, the card slides back up and out with a lighter, faster motion, communicating 'no pressure, it is gone.' The sensation is an invitation that respects a declined response.
animation_feel.duration_range: 250ms entrance, 200ms dismissal (faster out than in, respecting the 'no thanks' decision)

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest sees accumulating unreviewed stays and feels guilty about not completing them, or feels burdened by the platform's persistent ask.
tension_relief.relief_point: With batched reviews, the Stays Manager shows no review obligations on 10 out of 13 weekly visits. The three review moments are framed as invitations, not demands. Dismissing a review prompt has no visible consequence -- no accumulating badge, no guilt signal.
tension_relief.timing: The relief is structural, not momentary: the guest feels lighter on every visit because the page never shows a to-do list. The three review moments each last one visit (if dismissed, they move to secondary position for 2 more visits, then disappear entirely).

personalization_signals: Review prompt references the specific weeks and dates covered, not generic 'your stays'
If the guest submitted a previous batched review, the midpoint review acknowledges it: 'You shared your thoughts at Week 4. How have things been since?'
If the guest's prior review was negative, the review prompt gently checks in: 'You flagged some concerns at Week 4. Have things improved?'
Final review uses a warm lease-end framing: 'Your time at [property] is wrapping up. Looking back, how was it?'

anti_patterns.pattern: Displaying a 'Review' button on every completed stay row in the Stays Table
anti_patterns.reason: Accumulating review buttons create a guilt accumulator that worsens on every visit. By Week 8, the guest sees 5+ unreviewed stays, which makes the Stays Manager feel like a list of failures rather than a helpful dashboard. The emotional contamination from this pattern poisons the guest's entire experience of the page they visit most often.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Week 1: [Review] | Week 2: [Review] | Week 3: [Review] | Week 4: [Review] | Week 5: [Review] -- all visible simultaneously in the stays table.

elements.title: Mutual Pledge Card
elements.problem: Booking feels like a one-way consumer transaction rather than two people choosing each other, producing weak commitments that lead to cancellations and distrust.
elements.solution: A split-screen commitment card shown at the acceptance stage of the proposal flow. The left half shows the host's pledge (welcome message, what they commit to providing, their expectations), and the right half shows the guest's pledge (introduction, what they commit to respecting, their stay purpose). Both sides fill in progressively as each party contributes, and a central 'handshake' visual locks when both pledges are complete. The card becomes a permanent artifact visible to both parties throughout the lease.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: People-Like-You Review Filter
elements.problem: Reviews are an undifferentiated mass  a 4.9 from 200 people tells you nothing about whether people in YOUR situation had a good experience, leaving the most persuasive form of social proof (similarity-matched) completely untapped.
elements.solution: A review section enhancement for the listing page that adds horizontally scrollable filter chips above the reviews. Chips represent stay-context categories: 'Remote Workers,' 'Traveling Nurses,' 'Relocating,' '4+ Week Stays,' 'Solo Guests.' Selecting a chip filters reviews to show only those from matching guests, with a summary stat: 'Remote workers rate this space 4.8  workspace quality highlighted in 12 of 15 reviews.' When no filter is active, the full aggregate view shows. A small 'people like you' badge auto-suggests a filter based on the guest's profile.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide
elements.problem: The messaging interface is a blank pipe  neither host nor guest knows what to say, when to say it, or whether communication is even expected, causing pluralistic ignorance that suppresses the trust-building micro-commitments that predict stay satisfaction.
elements.solution: A guided conversation module that appears in the messaging thread between acceptance and move-in. It presents 3-4 suggested conversation topics as expandable cards: 'Arrival Details,' 'Workspace Setup,' 'House Rhythm,' and 'Neighborhood Tips.' Each card includes a pre-written message template the guest can customize and send. A subtle social proof line reads 'Most guests discuss these topics before arriving.' As each topic is covered, it checks off with a satisfying micro-animation. The guide is suggestive, not mandatory  it can be collapsed at any time.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge
elements.problem: The post-review moment  when the guest has just publicly committed to a positive narrative  is the peak of psychological consistency pressure, but every platform treats it as a dead end instead of a bridge to the next commitment.
elements.solution: A card that appears immediately after the guest submits a positive review (4+ stars). Instead of a generic 'Thanks for your review,' it reflects the guest's own words back to them and offers three forward-commitment paths: (1) Save this host for next time, (2) See this host's upcoming availability, (3) Share your experience to help someone like you find this space. It also surfaces the guest's emerging identity: 'You've now stayed with 3 hosts across 2 cities on Split Lease.' The card is warm, personal, and leverages the peak moment.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Stay Purpose Selector
elements.problem: Guests arrive at search as anonymous browsers with unspoken, uncommitted preferences  the platform never asks who they are or what they need, leaving the most powerful commitment device (visible preference declaration) completely unused.
elements.solution: A lightweight preference declaration step that appears at the top of the search experience. Three large, illustrated tap targets ask: 'What brings you to Split Lease?' with options like 'Working remotely,' 'Traveling for work,' 'Relocating.' Selecting one triggers a follow-up: 'What matters most?' with 2-3 quick-pick priority chips (e.g., 'Quiet workspace,' 'Close to transit,' 'Budget-friendly'). The selections persist as a visible bar above search results: 'Remote Worker  Workspace matters most.' This bar creates the commitment anchor that Cialdini predicts will drive decisive action.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Commitment Reassurance Badge
elements.problem: At the peak commitment moment  when the guest is about to submit a proposal  there is zero social proof to reassure them, creating a 'checkout desert' where doubt is highest and psychological support is absent.
elements.solution: A compact reassurance badge that appears on the proposal summary screen, just above the 'Submit Proposal' button. It contains two pieces of dynamically-generated social proof: (1) a host satisfaction metric ('Guests who stayed with Sarah rated their experience 4.9/5') and (2) a commitment-specific reassurance ('97% of guests who proposed to this host had their proposal accepted'). The badge is subtle  it doesn't scream  but its placement at the peak uncertainty moment leverages Cialdini's finding that social proof is most influential during uncertainty.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.name: Stay-Cycle Micro-Review Pulse
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the impossible task of compressing 90 days into a single retrospective form with a one-tap weekly pulse that captures impressions at the moment of peak recall.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor has per-stay-cycle review capture because OTAs have no concept of stay cycles within a lease -- their data model treats every booking as an atomic event with one review opportunity, while Split Lease's Stays Manager creates 13+ natural touchpoints per lease.
elements.description: A compact card that appears at the bottom of the Stays Manager after each weekly stay is marked complete. It shows the stay dates, asks a single sentiment question ('How was this stay?') via three emoji-free tap targets (Great / Fine / Rough), and optionally expands for a one-line note. The card is non-blocking -- the guest can dismiss it and return later. Over 13+ stays, these micro-pulses accumulate into a rich temporal review narrative visible on the guest's review timeline.

elements.name: Stay-Cycle Review Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: Transforms accumulated micro-review pulses into a visible temporal narrative that rewards the reviewer with a sense of growing contribution and gives future guests a chronological view of the stay experience no competitor offers.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor structures reviews around the chronological phases of a stay because they treat every booking as a single atomic event -- Split Lease is the only platform with per-stay-cycle data to render a temporal review narrative.
elements.description: A horizontal timeline visualization that appears both in the guest's own review history (Reward of the Self) and on the property listing for future guests (Reward of the Hunt). elements.name: Vetting Trust Shield
elements.problem_it_solves: Fills the trust desert for new and low-review listings by surfacing operational vetting data that Split Lease already collects -- employment verification, credit checks, landlord references -- as visible trust signals that function as pre-booking review equivalents.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No OTA performs deep vetting (employment, credit, landlord references) because their business model does not justify it for 2-night stays -- Split Lease already has this data as a core business process, making it a zero-cost trust signal that competitors cannot acquire without rebuilding their entire onboarding.
elements.description: A compact trust shield card that appears on every listing, replacing the empty review section for new properties with concrete operational data. It displays verification badges (ID verified, employment verified, credit checked), behavioral metrics from platform data (average host response time, lease renewal rate, guest completion rate), and vetting status for incoming guests. The card resolves the internal trigger of commitment anxiety ('Is this legit?') that Tag, Patricia, Michael, and Susan all expressed in transcripts, using data the platform already possesses.

elements.name: Priority Picker at Proposal
elements.problem_it_solves: Seeds the review habit at the moment of highest commitment by capturing what matters most to the guest, creating a personalized scaffold that transforms the post-lease review from a generic hotel form into a guided reflection the guest primed themselves for.

These selections are stored and later used to scaffold micro-review prompts and the end-of-lease synthesis. elements.name: Trusted Reviewer Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Creates the reviewer identity and visible impact that Booking.com's anonymous system completely lacks, transforming review contributions from disposable civic acts into accumulated reputation that delivers all three of Eyal's variable reward types: Tribe (social recognition), Hunt (impact metrics), and Self (trust tier achievement).
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform has built a reviewer identity system for housing because high-volume OTAs do not need individual reviewer retention -- their volume compensates for any reviewer's absence, while Split Lease's low-volume long-stay model makes every reviewer critical.

elements.name: Passive Signal Dashboard Row
elements.problem_it_solves: Converts communication and behavioral data the platform already captures -- message response times, maintenance resolution speed, date change frequency, renewal rates -- into visible review-equivalent quality signals that generate trust without requiring anyone to write a single word.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor synthesizes behavioral data into visible quality signals because OTAs' 2-night bookings generate too few data points for statistically meaningful behavioral scores -- Split Lease's multi-month leases with weekly stays generate hundreds of data points per tenancy.
elements.description: A horizontal row of behavioral metric cards that appears in two contexts: (1) on the listing page below traditional reviews, showing aggregated host behavioral data, and (2) on the host's own dashboard, showing their performance metrics. Each card displays a single behavioral signal with a clear label, the metric value, and a subtle data source indicator ('Based on 47 messages across 6 guests'). The metrics are operational facts, not opinions -- they supplement traditional reviews with verifiable behavioral evidence.

Never show individual data points -- always aggregate across guests
Never surface negative signals without context (e.g., a slow response might mean the host was traveling)

elements.name: End-of-Lease Review Synthesis Modal
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the cold-start retrospective review form with a synthesis of signals already captured, presenting the guest's own micro-review pulses and priority evaluations back to them for confirmation and optional elaboration -- transforming the review from a 15-minute cognitive exercise into a 2-minute reflection that feels like closing a chapter, not filling out a tax form.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor can build a synthesis review because they have no mid-stay data to synthesize -- they must start from scratch at checkout, while Split Lease's accumulated micro-pulses, priority ratings, and passive signals provide a rich foundation that the guest merely confirms.
elements.description: A full-screen modal that appears when the guest's lease ends. It presents: (1) their stay journey timeline with all micro-pulses visualized, (2) their stated priorities from proposal time with current ratings pre-filled from pulse data, (3) a single open text prompt for anything they want to add, and (4) an impact preview showing how their review will appear to future guests. The modal celebrates the completion ('13 weeks reviewed -- thank you') and shows the guest their Reviewer Profile card updated with this contribution. The Variable Reward is immediate and multi-dimensional: Tribe (your review joins the community), Hunt (your priorities are now scored), Self (your timeline is complete).

elements.title: Replace the Human Signifier with a Coherent System Image
elements.problem: The platform has no independent system image. Susan's entire interaction with Split Lease is mediated by Bryant  a human being who serves as the sole signifier for the service's identity, operational model, and trustworthiness. Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'), requiring Bryant to verbally correct her conceptual model. She never encounters the platform's interface, search page, or listing page. Norman's system image principle states that 'the designer of the product and the person using the product form somewhat disconnected vertices of a triangle' and 'the entire burden of communication is on the system image.' Split Lease's system image does not exist independently of Bryant. If Bryant is removed from the interaction, the user has no triangle vertex to form a conceptual model from  the system image collapses entirely.
elements.solution: Build a system image that can communicate Split Lease's identity, purpose, and operational model without human mediation. This requires: (1) The landing page must signify what Split Lease IS within 5 seconds  not 'a marketplace' (too generic) but 'part-time housing: book the nights you need, not the ones you don't.' The signifier must be perceivable to someone whose existing conceptual model of housing is 'full-time occupancy.' (2) Every page must carry the core signifier: this is not a hotel, not Airbnb, not a real estate brokerage  it is schedule-native shared housing. The system image must be consistent across all touchpoints so the guest can form one coherent conceptual model. (3) The first interaction should not require Bryant. A guest who arrives at the site via a link, a search result, or a referral must be able to understand what actions are possible (Norman's discoverability) without calling anyone. (4) When a human intermediary IS involved, the platform should bridge from the human to the digital: Bryant's name, the listing discussed, and the terms mentioned should appear on the platform so it feels like a continuation of the conversation, not a disconnected system.

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that the platform communicates nothing about itself. Her conceptual model defaults to the closest familiar category (real estate brokerage) because Split Lease's actual category has no signifier she can perceive.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device. If it is incomplete or contradictory, there will be trouble.
evidence.insight: Split Lease's system image is not merely incoherent  it is absent. The user's only available system image is Bryant's verbal explanation, which is ephemeral and cannot be revisited.

evidence.quote: I'm looking for a guest who would need this space basically for any non-continuous set of nights... Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to 'seven nights a week' because her conceptual model of housing does not include non-continuous occupancy. The platform's core value proposition has no signifier that would correct this model without human intervention.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: Susan cannot discover what Split Lease does, let alone what actions it affords. Discoverability requires affordances, signifiers, constraints, mappings, and feedback working together  none of which Susan encounters from the platform itself.

elements.user_goal: Understand within seconds what this service is, what it offers, and whether it can solve my specific problem  without needing to talk to a human first.
elements.company_goal: Enable platform-mediated discovery and conversion so that growth is not bottlenecked by the number of human intermediaries available to explain the service.
elements.time_budget: Under 10 seconds to form a correct conceptual model of what Split Lease is. Under 30 seconds to understand whether any listings match the guest's needs.
anti_goals: DO NOT rely on marketing language that describes the company rather than signifying what the user can do. 'We connect hosts and guests' is not a signifier. 'Book 3 nights a week in a private room near Lincoln Tunnel' is.
DO NOT use internal jargon ('non-continuous set of nights', 'lease style', 'periodic tenancy') as user-facing signifiers. These terms require human translation.
DO NOT hide the human fallback. Some guests will always need to talk to someone. The platform should make this accessible, not eliminate it.
elements.success_metric: First-visit comprehension rate: percentage of new visitors who can correctly describe what Split Lease does after 30 seconds on the landing page (testable via 5-second usability tests). Target: above 70%.

elements.title: Surface Trust Signifiers That Replace Physical Inspection
elements.problem: Susan demands to physically inspect the space three times in the call (2:14, 3:05, 3:42). She is told that pre-booking inspection is not allowed for privacy reasons. This creates an anti-affordance  a deliberate prevention of interaction  but the anti-affordance has no discoverable signifier explaining WHY it exists or WHAT substitutes are available. Norman states that anti-affordances must be discoverable and perceivable, or the user will walk into the glass wall. Susan's prior experience with housing scams ('you know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around,' 2:22) means her default conceptual model for remote housing is 'likely fraud.' The listing page's current signifiers  whatever they may be  are insufficient to overcome this default model. Susan explicitly proposes photos as a substitute signifier (3:42), and Bryant improvises a first-night cancellation guarantee (3:16), but neither of these critical affordances is discoverable through the platform itself.
elements.solution: Build a layered trust signifier system that makes the anti-affordance (no pre-booking inspection) acceptable by making its substitutes prominently discoverable. This requires: (1) Verified photos as primary trust signifiers  not optional, not thumbnail-sized, but prominent, labeled as verified, and comprehensive (room, bathroom, common areas, building entrance). Susan specifically asked about the room and bathroom (1:08); the photos must cover exactly what guests ask about. (2) First-night cancellation guarantee as a prominently displayed signifier on the listing page and the acceptance screen. Bryant invented this on the fly (3:16); it must be a permanent, discoverable platform affordance. (3) Host identity verification signifiers  verified name, photo, response rate, reviews from prior guests. These replace the face-to-face meeting that Susan's friend cannot have because she is in Oregon. (4) An explicit signifier explaining the no-preview policy: 'For the host's privacy, we don't offer pre-booking tours. Instead, here's how we verify every listing...' Norman's principle: when you cannot make the anti-affordance invisible (like good glass), you must provide a signifier that explains it and directs the user to the substitute affordance.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for physical inspection is a trust requirement, not a preference. Her past scam experiences have created a conceptual model where remote housing = fraud until proven otherwise. The platform must provide signifiers that directly address this mental model.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable  perceivable. This poses a difficulty with glass... If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is a glass wall. Susan runs into it repeatedly. The platform needs a signifier that makes this anti-affordance perceivable AND directs the guest toward the substitute affordances (photos, reviews, cancellation guarantee).

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant improvises the single most important trust affordance in the entire call  first-night cancellation. This affordance exists only in Bryant's verbal promise, not as a discoverable platform feature. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.'

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan spontaneously identifies photos as the acceptable substitute signifier for physical inspection, and immediately couples it with readiness to pay. The conversion path is: verified photos  trust  deposit. Missing photos = missing the entire conversion mechanism.

elements.user_goal: Know that the space is real, safe, and as described before committing money or booking travel  without needing to visit in person.
elements.company_goal: Convert trust-anxious guests by providing discoverable verification signifiers that eliminate the need for human-mediated trust building at the listing evaluation stage.
elements.time_budget: Trust signifiers must be visible within the first scroll of the listing page. The guest should not need to click into a separate section to find verification status, cancellation terms, or host identity.
anti_goals: DO NOT bury trust signifiers below the fold or behind expandable sections. If the guest must search for trust evidence, the signifier has failed.
DO NOT treat photos as optional or host-controlled quality. If photos are the primary substitute for physical inspection, they must be verified, comprehensive, and recent.
DO NOT present the cancellation guarantee only in legal fine print. It is the most important trust affordance and must be signified with the same visual prominence as the price.

DO NOT assume that trust is built once. Susan asked about legitimacy at three different points in the call  trust signifiers must be reinforced at listing evaluation, negotiation, acceptance, AND move-in.
elements.success_metric: Listing-to-proposal conversion rate for first-time guests who have not spoken to an agent. Target: above 15% (vs. current agent-mediated conversion). Secondary: percentage of listings with verified photos above 90%.

elements.title: Map Platform Controls to the Guest's Natural Language, Not Platform Terminology
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11), weekday names ('Monday to Friday,' implied by 'five nights a week'), and space types ('full apartment or bedroom,' 0:43). The platform thinks in night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35), lease styles, and feature taxonomies. Bryant must perform the mapping between these two vocabularies in real time  twice for the non-continuous nights concept (0:19-0:35 and 1:35-2:00) and once for the minimum stay requirement. Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' The platform's input controls must map to the guest's natural way of thinking about their stay, not require the guest to translate their needs into platform-native units. When the mapping is unnatural, the guest cannot operate the controls correctly  or at all.
elements.solution: Design every input control to accept the guest's natural vocabulary and translate internally. This requires: (1) Duration selection: let guests select 'about 1 month' or 'about 2 months' and show the equivalent night count as secondary information ('approximately 30 nights'). Do not present a number field labeled 'nights.' (2) Schedule selection: provide one-click presets for common patterns  'Weekdays (Mon-Fri),' 'Weekends (Sat-Sun),' 'Full week'  rather than requiring individual day toggles. Susan's friend needs 'Monday to Friday,' which should be a single tap. (3) Space type: use labels guests naturally use ('Private room with private bath,' 'Shared room,' 'Full apartment') rather than feature taxonomies. Susan asked 'is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?'  those are the categories. (4) Location: show a map with neighborhood labels and transit proximity, not just a street address. Susan immediately oriented around the Lincoln Tunnel (5:35); the listing should signify proximity to landmarks the guest knows. (5) Every control should provide immediate visual feedback showing the mapping: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, starting March 3.' This is the real-time translation Bryant performed verbally at 1:35-2:00.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. The non-continuous nights concept requires a signifier that communicates the model without jargon. 'Non-continuous set of nights' is platform language; 'pick the nights you need' is guest language.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding. For example, to move an object up, move the control up.
evidence.insight: A calendar-based duration selector where the guest taps weeks on a visual calendar is a natural mapping. A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires cognitive translation.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant performs the mapping between Susan's '1-2 months' and the platform's '30 night minimum' in real time. The proposal creation UI must perform this same mapping visually  showing the guest both their natural-language description and the platform's internal calculation simultaneously.

evidence.quote: When the model presented to us is inadequate or wrong (or, worse, nonexistent), we can have difficulties.
evidence.insight: Norman's refrigerator example shows that controls labeled in the system's vocabulary (freezer dial vs. temperature dial) create false conceptual models. Labels must use the user's vocabulary to create correct mental models of what the controls do.

elements.user_goal: Express my housing needs using words I already know  months, weekdays, private room  and have the platform understand me without requiring me to learn its terminology.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate the vocabulary translation barrier that prevents self-service booking, reducing dependency on human intermediaries to interpret guest needs.
elements.time_budget: Configuring a stay proposal (dates, schedule, duration) should take under 60 seconds using preset-based natural mappings. If the guest must think about how to express their need in platform terms, the mapping has failed.
anti_goals: DO NOT present minimum night counts as the primary framing for duration. Guests think in weeks and months, not night totals.
DO NOT require toggling individual days when a preset ('Weekdays') captures the intent in one tap.
DO NOT use dropdown menus with platform taxonomy categories. Use the guest's own vocabulary as labels.
DO NOT hide the platform's internal calculation. Show both: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months' AND '40 nights at $X/night = $Y total.' Transparency builds the correct conceptual model.
elements.success_metric: Proposal creation completion rate for unassisted guests (no agent involvement). Target: above 50%. Secondary: average time from search to submitted proposal under 5 minutes.

elements.title: Provide Immediate, Informative Feedback at Every Negotiation Action
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a real-time negotiation: Susan demands inspection, Bryant explains the policy, Susan pushes back, Bryant offers a compromise (first-night cancellation). At every exchange, both parties receive immediate verbal feedback  acknowledgment, explanation, counter-proposal. The platform's negotiation flow must replicate this feedback density, but digital interactions are prone to feedback gaps: submitted proposals that show 'pending' for days, counter-offers that arrive with no notification, status changes that are invisible unless the guest happens to check. Norman states that 'feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.' The call itself demonstrates this: when the phone connection drops at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?'  trust erodes within seconds of lost feedback. Every minute a guest waits for a response to a proposal, a date change request, or a negotiation counter is a minute their trust decays.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation and active lease flows with Norman's feedback hierarchy: immediate acknowledgment, informative status, and prioritized notifications. This requires: (1) Every guest action (submit proposal, request date change, send message, accept terms) must produce immediate visual feedback confirming the action was registered  not a spinner, but a contextual confirmation ('Your proposal has been sent to Rita. She typically responds within 4 hours.'). (2) Status updates must be pushed, not polled. The guest should never have to check whether something happened. Notifications must arrive via the guest's preferred channel (push notification, email, SMS) within minutes. (3) Feedback must be informative, not just confirmatory. 'Your date change was approved' is better than a green checkmark. 'Rita approved your date change. Your next stay is Monday March 10' is better still. (4) When delays are unavoidable (host has not responded), the platform must provide intermediate feedback: 'Rita has not yet responded. Most hosts respond within 6 hours. We will notify you immediately.' This is the digital equivalent of Bryant saying 'I'll keep you updated' (6:57). (5) Prioritize feedback: routine confirmations (stay confirmed) should be unobtrusive; critical actions (proposal rejected, date change denied, payment failed) must capture attention.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap on the phone call causes immediate anxiety and both parties scramble to re-establish communication. This is exactly what happens when a platform shows 'pending' for hours  the guest's trust erodes because the feedback channel appears broken.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: Norman's 0.1-second threshold is about perceived responsiveness. For asynchronous actions like proposals, 'immediate' means instant acknowledgment of the action plus a realistic timeline for the outcome. The guest must never wonder whether their action registered.

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant promises future feedback as the call ends. This human promise of ongoing communication is the only signifier Susan has for what happens next. The platform must replace this promise with systematic, reliable status notifications.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The active lease generates many feedback moments (date confirmations, cleaning reminders, payment receipts). Each must be prioritized: critical signals (payment failed, host cancellation) must break through; routine signals (stay confirmed) should not become the 'backseat driver' Norman warns about.

elements.user_goal: Always know what is happening with my booking  whether my action was received, what the host decided, and what I should do next  without needing to check or call someone.
elements.company_goal: Reduce abandonment during asynchronous negotiation by replacing feedback gaps with proactive status communication that maintains guest engagement across the waiting period.
elements.time_budget: Action acknowledgment: under 1 second. Status update delivery: under 5 minutes for critical actions, under 1 hour for routine actions. Intermediate 'still waiting' feedback: every 6 hours for proposals, every 2 hours for time-sensitive requests.
anti_goals: DO NOT show a generic 'pending' state without a timeline. The guest must know when to expect a response.

DO NOT over-notify for routine events. Norman: 'Too much feedback can be even more annoying than too little.' Cleaning reminders and weekly stay confirmations should be quiet; payment failures and host cancellations should be loud.
DO NOT use identical notification patterns for different event types. If every notification looks the same, the guest will ignore all of them.
DO NOT replace human communication with automated messages that feel robotic. Status updates should feel informative and specific, not template-generated.
elements.success_metric: Guest engagement during negotiation: percentage of guests who remain active on the platform (checking status, responding to counter-offers) during the proposal-to-acceptance window. Target: above 60% still engaged after 24 hours. Secondary: average response time to host counter-offers under 4 hours.

elements.title: Support Proxy Booking as a First-Class Affordance
elements.problem: Susan is not the guest  she is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34), 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31), and 'before she puts her tickets' (2:14). The platform's conceptual model assumes the person searching, evaluating, proposing, and paying is the person who will stay. Norman's conceptual model principle states that 'a conceptual model is an explanation, usually highly simplified, of how something works. It doesn't have to be complete or even accurate as long as it is useful.' The one-guest-one-user model is not useful when proxies are involved. The platform affords booking (you can fill out forms and pay), but it does not signify proxy booking (there is no discoverable way to indicate 'I am booking for someone else'). The affordance may exist but without a signifier it is invisible. Susan would have to either pretend to be the guest or improvise a workaround  both of which create incorrect data and a broken conceptual model.
elements.solution: Make proxy booking a discoverable, signified affordance at every relevant phase. This requires: (1) During account creation or proposal creation, provide a clear signifier: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' This single toggle changes the conceptual model from one-user to two-user and adjusts subsequent fields accordingly. (2) In the proposal, capture both the proxy's information (Susan: contact person, local presence, deposit payer) and the guest's information (friend: actual occupant, arrival date, Oregon address). (3) During the active lease, afford dual communication: both the proxy and the guest should receive status updates, feedback, and action prompts. Susan is coordinating locally; the friend is occupying remotely. Both need different information at different times. (4) The acceptance flow must clearly signify who is committing to what: the proxy commits the deposit, the guest commits to the stay. These are different actions by different people and must be signified as such. (5) Norman's constraint principle applies: the proxy's affordances should be constrained to coordination actions (pay deposit, communicate with host, manage schedule), while the guest's affordances include occupancy actions (check in, submit cleaning photos, write reviews).

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly describes the proxy pattern: she inspects and pays, the friend occupies. The platform must afford this split-responsibility pattern, not force all actions through a single account.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: If the platform offers no signifier for proxy booking, a proxy user like Susan will not know it is possible, will not find the right path, and will either abandon or create a distorted booking under her own name.

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: Susan is managing her friend's schedule from a different location. During the active lease, the platform must support this distributed coordination pattern  one person managing logistics locally while another occupies the space.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products: good communication is the key to good conceptual models.
evidence.insight: The platform's conceptual model must communicate a two-person booking structure clearly: who is the coordinator, who is the occupant, what can each person do. Without this, both users will struggle to understand their roles and available actions.

elements.user_goal: Book and manage a stay for someone else  paying the deposit, coordinating with the host, and receiving updates  without pretending to be the person who will actually stay there.
elements.company_goal: Capture a booking pattern that currently requires human mediation (Bryant coordinating between Susan and Rita) by making proxy booking self-service, expanding the addressable market to guests who are assisted by local contacts.
elements.time_budget: The proxy/self toggle should add no more than 10 seconds to the proposal flow. Subsequent dual-user fields should be pre-structured so both profiles can be completed in under 2 minutes total.
anti_goals: DO NOT force all actions through a single user account. The proxy and the guest are different people with different needs and different affordances.
DO NOT ignore the proxy after booking. Susan is the local contact, the deposit payer, and the schedule coordinator  she needs ongoing access and feedback, not just the initial payment form.

DO NOT require the guest to be present on the platform to complete the booking. If the friend is in Oregon with no account, Susan must be able to book on her behalf without the friend creating a profile first.
DO NOT treat proxy booking as an edge case hidden in settings. If it requires more than one click to discover, the signifier has failed for this user segment.
elements.success_metric: Proxy booking utilization rate: percentage of bookings where the paying user and the occupying user are different people, completed without agent assistance. Target: above 10% of all bookings. Secondary: proxy booking completion rate above 60% (vs. abandonment due to inability to express the proxy pattern).

elements.title: Bridge the Signifier-to-Reality Gap at Move-In with Knowledge-in-the-World
elements.problem: Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure. Her friend is flying from Oregon  the cost of a bad experience is not just the booking fee but an airline ticket, lost time, and a stranded person in an unfamiliar city. The listing page's signifiers (photos, description, price) make promises about the space. Move-in is the moment those promises are tested against reality. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers from the listing) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available in the environment at the moment of action). At move-in, the guest's knowledge in the head is limited and potentially distorted by the listing's signifiers. The guest needs knowledge in the world: how to enter the building, how to find the room, how to use the Wi-Fi, how to contact the host if something is wrong, and critically  how to exercise the cancellation guarantee if the space does not match the listing. None of this is discoverable from the space itself. The House Manual is the primary vehicle for delivering knowledge in the world, but only if it is accessible, complete, and organized around the guest's move-in sequence.
elements.solution: Design the move-in experience as a signifier-to-reality bridge that provides knowledge in the world at the exact moment the guest needs it. This requires: (1) A digital House Manual that is accessible from the guest's phone, organized chronologically by move-in sequence: access the building  find the room  check the space  connect to Wi-Fi  review the cancellation terms  contact the host. Not alphabetically. Not by topic. By the guest's actual action sequence. (2) The cancellation guarantee must be the most prominent signifier in the move-in flow, not buried in terms and conditions. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' The guest must know they can leave on night one if the space does not match. (3) A move-in checklist that asks the guest to verify key claims from the listing: private bathroom? check. Private room? check. Wi-Fi works? check. This serves dual purpose: it gives the guest a structured way to verify (reducing anxiety) and it gives the platform data on listing accuracy. (4) Co-occupancy must be disclosed and discoverable before and during move-in. Susan asked 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). If the guest arrives to unexpected co-occupants, every prior signifier is invalidated. (5) A clear, signified feedback channel for move-in problems: a button or contact method that is visible on the first screen of the House Manual, not buried three levels deep.

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is specifically about the gap between listing claims and physical reality. The move-in experience must close this gap immediately  within the first 10 minutes of arrival  or the trust built through listing evaluation and negotiation collapses.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest must discover how to enter the building, access the room, use facilities, and contact the host  all without prior physical experience. Every one of these is an affordance that requires a signifier in the House Manual or check-in flow.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is a critical move-in variable. If the guest discovers unexpected co-occupants at arrival, the listing's signifiers have failed catastrophically. This must be disclosed before move-in and verified at move-in.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly; we do operations as we were told to do them; we can't fully appreciate why, what effects to expect, or what to do if things go wrong.
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest needs a conceptual model of the space and its rules  not just the physical layout but the social contract: when to be quiet, how to handle shared spaces, what the host expects. The House Manual must provide this model, organized as knowledge-in-the-world that is available exactly when and where the guest needs it.

elements.user_goal: Arrive at the space and immediately know how to get in, verify it matches the listing, understand the rules, and know what to do if something is wrong  all from my phone, without calling anyone.
elements.company_goal: Prevent move-in failures that result in cancellations, negative reviews, and lost referral chains (Susan  friend  future word-of-mouth) by ensuring the physical experience matches the digital signifiers.
elements.time_budget: The guest should be able to access the building, enter the room, and confirm the space matches the listing within 15 minutes of arrival. The House Manual should be accessible in under 3 taps from the app home screen.
anti_goals: DO NOT organize the House Manual by topic (Wi-Fi, Appliances, Neighborhood). Organize it by the guest's action sequence at move-in.
DO NOT bury the cancellation guarantee in fine print. At move-in, it is the most important signifier  it is the safety net that made this entire booking possible.
DO NOT assume the guest will read the House Manual before arrival. It must be designed for just-in-time reference at the moment of need, not for advance study.
DO NOT rely solely on the host to communicate move-in details. The platform must have a structured, verified move-in flow that does not depend on the host remembering to send check-in instructions.
elements.success_metric: First-night cancellation rate: target below 5% (indicating that listing signifiers accurately predict reality). Secondary: move-in checklist completion rate above 70% (indicating guests are using the verification tool and finding it matches their needs).

elements.title: Layered Trust Verification Stack: Substitute Signifiers for Physical Inspection
elements.problem: Susan demands to physically inspect the space three times (2:14, 3:05, 3:42) because the listing's current signifiers are insufficient to replace the affordance of seeing the space in person. The platform enforces a no-preview policy (anti-affordance) for the host's privacy, but this anti-affordance has no discoverable substitute signifier. Susan does not learn about the first-night cancellation guarantee until Bryant improvises it verbally (3:16). She does not see verified photos because none are presented during the call. Her friend is flying from Oregon  the cost of a wrong decision is an airline ticket plus the booking, making the stakes catastrophically high. Norman states: 'To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable  perceivable. If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.' The listing page must structure its trust information so that substitute signifiers for physical inspection are the first things the guest perceives, not supplementary details buried below property features.
elements.solution: Structure the listing page's information hierarchy so that trust verification signifiers occupy the primary visual position, above property features. The hierarchy is: (1) Verified photo gallery with a 'Verified by Split Lease' badge and timestamp  photos must cover the exact elements Susan asked about: room, bathroom (1:08), common areas, building entrance. (2) First-night cancellation guarantee displayed with the same visual prominence as the nightly rate  not in terms and conditions, not in a tooltip, but as a peer-level signifier alongside price. (3) Host identity verification: verified name, photo, response time, and number of prior guests. (4) A brief explanation of the no-preview policy: 'For the host's privacy, tours aren't available before booking. Here is how we verify every listing instead...' This transforms the anti-affordance from a glass wall into a signified constraint with visible alternatives. The pattern is: explain what you prevent, then immediately signify what you provide instead.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for inspection is a trust requirement rooted in prior scam experiences. Her default conceptual model for remote housing is 'likely fraud until physically verified.' The listing page's information architecture must directly counteract this model with verification signifiers that are perceivable within the first scroll.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable  perceivable. This poses a difficulty with glass... If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is a glass wall. Susan runs into it three times without understanding why it exists or what alternatives are available. The listing page must signify both the anti-affordance (why no tours) and the substitute affordances (verified photos, cancellation guarantee, host verification).

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant improvises the most critical trust affordance in the entire call  the first-night cancellation guarantee. This affordance is invisible on the platform. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' This must become a primary signifier, not a hidden policy.

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan spontaneously identifies photos as the acceptable substitute for physical inspection AND immediately couples photos with readiness to pay. The conversion path is: verified photos seen  trust established  deposit offered. The information architecture must place photos at the top of this causal chain.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: verified photo gallery with verification badge and timestamp (trust evidence that replaces physical inspection). Secondary: first-night cancellation guarantee displayed as a peer signifier to nightly rate (safety net that makes the no-preview policy acceptable). Tertiary: host identity verification card with response metrics and guest count (social proof of legitimacy). The ordering follows Susan's decision sequence: see the space (photos)  know I can leave (cancellation)  know the host is real (verification).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on listing page load: verified photo gallery with badge, first-night guarantee callout, host identity card. All three are above the fold. On scroll: no-preview policy explanation with link to verification process. On the acceptance screen: cancellation terms restated with one-line summary. At move-in: cancellation guarantee re-signified in the House Manual's first section, with clear instructions on how to exercise it.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 trust signifiers visible simultaneously on the listing page (photos, cancellation badge, host card). Each signifier communicates its message in under 5 words of label text. The no-preview explanation is a maximum of 2 sentences. No legal language in the primary trust layer  legal terms are available on demand but never in the primary scan path.
scan_order: Verified photo gallery with 'Verified' badge (System 1 visual evidence: 'I can see the space', under 2 seconds)
First-night cancellation guarantee badge next to price (System 1 safety signal: 'I can leave if it is wrong', 2-4 seconds)
Host identity card with photo, name, response time (System 1 social proof: 'A real person is behind this', 4-6 seconds)
No-preview policy explanation (System 2, only if the guest wonders why tours are not available, 6+ seconds)
exclude: Trust signifiers buried below property features or amenity lists. Trust must be primary, not supplementary.
Cancellation terms presented only in legal fine print or a separate Terms page. The guarantee must be a visual signifier, not a legal document.
Unverified or host-uploaded-only photos without a platform verification badge. Unverified photos do not counteract Susan's 'run around' mental model.
Host identity displayed as a name-only text link. The host card must include a photo and response metrics to function as a social proof signifier.

elements.title: Platform Identity Signifier: Communicate What Split Lease Is Within One Scan
elements.problem: Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'). She does not understand the non-continuous nights model ('Like seven nights a week?' at 0:43) and requires Bryant to explain it three times across the call. Norman's discoverability principle requires that 'it be possible to figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them.' Susan cannot figure out what the service IS, let alone what actions it affords. The platform's core value proposition  schedule-native shared housing where guests book only the nights they need  has no perceivable signifier that a first-time visitor can process without human translation. Norman warns that 'hand-lettered signs pasted on products = poor design'  when you need to explain what something is, the design itself has failed. The landing page and every listing page must carry a signifier that communicates the non-continuous model in the guest's natural vocabulary, not platform jargon.
elements.solution: Every page must carry a persistent identity signifier that communicates Split Lease's model in the guest's vocabulary. The landing page's primary headline must signify the core concept in one sentence using natural language: 'Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.' Not 'non-continuous set of nights.' Not 'periodic tenancy marketplace.' Not 'schedule-native housing platform.' The guest's vocabulary is: nights, weekdays, months, private room. On listing pages, the identity signifier appears as a compact contextual badge: 'Part-time stay: pick your nights'  visible on every listing card and at the top of every listing detail page. In search, the available schedule pattern is the first filter dimension, not buried behind location or price: 'When do you need the space?' with presets for 'Weekdays,' 'Weekends,' 'Full week.' The pattern is: every page answers 'What is this service?' before answering 'What does this listing offer?'

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that the platform communicates nothing about its category or model. Her System 1 defaults to the closest familiar category (real estate brokerage) because Split Lease's actual category has no perceivable signifier. The information architecture must prevent this miscategorization by making the model self-evident.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. 'Non-continuous set of nights' is platform language that fails as a signifier. The information architecture must use the guest's own vocabulary to communicate the part-time model: 'pick your nights,' 'weekdays only,' 'book 3 nights a week.'

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: Norman's signifier principle applies at the service level, not just the UI level. Before the guest evaluates any listing, they must understand what kind of service they are using. The signifier 'Book the nights you need' communicates both the service model and the primary action in one phrase.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device. If it is incomplete or contradictory, there will be trouble.
