Flagged items expand with a smooth, unhurried reveal. The cancellation banner sits at the bottom of the screen with the solidity of a foundation. Nothing at move-in should feel playful, surprising, or attention-demanding. Every motion should feel deliberate and supportive, like a hand steadying your shoulder.

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest enters the space for the first time. The tension is: 'Does this match the listing? Am I safe here? What if it is not what I expected?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Each verified checklist item is a micro-relief. All items confirmed is the full relief: 'Everything matches. I am safe.' If items are flagged, the relief shifts to the safety net: 'Something is wrong, but I know what to do about it.'
tension_relief.timing: The full verification checklist should take 3-5 minutes. Each item produces its own micro-relief within 1 second of the guest's tap. The cancellation banner is visible the entire time.

personalization_signals: Populate the verification checklist from the actual listing claims: if the listing said 'Private bathroom,' the checklist item says 'Private bathroom' not a generic 'Bathroom check'
If the guest mentioned medical needs during booking, include a relevant checklist item: 'Elevator access as described'
Show the host's name and a one-tap contact button: 'Need help? Contact Rita' feels personal; 'Contact Support' feels institutional

anti_patterns.pattern: Dense welcome document delivered as a PDF or long email before arrival
anti_patterns.reason: A guest who receives a 3-page PDF with house rules, neighborhood tips, Wi-Fi instructions, and emergency contacts all at once will not read any of it. At move-in, cognitive capacity is consumed by the physical experience. Information must arrive one step at a time, at the moment of need, not as a pre-loaded dump.
anti_patterns.example_bad: An email 48 hours before arrival: 'Please review the attached House Manual (PDF, 8 pages) before your arrival. Important: memorize the access code and parking instructions.'

anti_patterns.pattern: Move-in screen that leads with house rules before access instructions
anti_patterns.reason: The guest's first need at move-in is physical access: get into the building, get into the room. House rules are irrelevant until the guest is inside and settled. Leading with rules feels like being lectured on the doorstep. Leading with access feels like being helped through the door.
anti_patterns.example_bad: House Manual opens to: 'Welcome! Before entering, please review the following house rules: 1. No shoes inside. 2. Quiet hours 10pm-8am. 3. Kitchen must be cleaned after use...' The guest is still standing outside.

elements.title: Settled Routine and Low-Friction Rhythm During Active Lease
elements.problem: Susan's friend will stay Monday through Friday, leave for the weekend, and return the following Monday. This creates a weekly cycle of mini-departures and mini-arrivals over 2 months. Each cycle is a micro version of the move-in experience: arrive, settle, use the space, leave. Norman's feedback principle warns that 'too much feedback can be even more annoying than too little.' During the active lease, the platform generates recurring feedback events: date confirmations, arrival notifications, cleaning reminders, payment confirmations, review prompts. If each of these demands the same attention as the initial move-in, the guest will experience notification fatigue and begin ignoring or resenting the platform. The emotional challenge is: how does the platform transition from the high-attention safety mode of move-in to the low-friction routine mode of an established stay? Susan's friend needs to feel that the platform supports her weekly rhythm without constantly demanding her attention.
elements.solution: After the first successful week, the platform's emotional register should shift from 'protective guide' to 'quiet companion.' Notifications become shorter and less frequent. Weekly stay confirmations are a single line in the Stays Manager, not a push notification. Date changes (if the friend needs to adjust for medical appointments) use the same familiar presets from proposal creation, producing a feeling of mastery ('I already know how to do this'). Cleaning photo reminders, if required, are gentle and brief: 'Quick photo before you leave Friday?' not 'Reminder: Upload cleaning verification photos as required by your lease agreement.' Review prompts, following the micro-review pattern from prior design stack runs, are one-tap interactions embedded in the Stays Manager, not modal interruptions. The emotional principle is: as the guest's familiarity grows, the platform's presence should shrink. The best active lease experience is one where the guest barely notices the platform because it runs as smoothly as her weekly routine.

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her... she could stay with a friend of mine if he need the space on the weekend.
evidence.insight: The friend's usage pattern is predictable and routinized: weekdays at the space, weekends elsewhere, appointments during the day. The platform must match this rhythm. Notifications should arrive at natural transition points (Friday departure, Monday arrival), not at arbitrary times.

evidence.quote: Too much feedback can be even more annoying than too little... Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive.
evidence.insight: Norman's warning about excessive feedback applies directly to the active lease phase. Every notification the platform sends during an 8-week stay competes with the guest's attention and tolerance. Routine confirmations must be unobtrusive. Only exceptional events (payment failure, host message, date change rejection) should demand attention.

evidence.quote: She could stay with a friend of mine if he need the space on the weekend, that would work.
evidence.insight: The friend has an alternative. If the platform's weekly friction exceeds the convenience of staying with Susan's other friend, the alternative expands from weekends to weekdays. The emotional threshold is: the platform must feel easier than coordinating with a friend. If it feels harder, the guest defects.

evidence.quote: A device is easy to use when the set of possible actions is visible, when the controls and displays exploit natural mappings.
evidence.insight: During the active lease, the guest uses the same controls repeatedly (Stays Manager, date tool, messaging). Familiarity should produce efficiency: each repeated use should feel faster and easier than the last. Norman's natural mapping principle means the controls should match the guest's now-established mental model of her weekly routine.

elements.emotion_rationale: During the active lease, the guest has moved past the high-tension phases (evaluation, negotiation, move-in). Her emotional need is ease: the feeling that the weekly routine runs smoothly, that the platform stays out of her way, and that occasional adjustments (date changes, schedule shifts) are effortless. Ease is not the same as delight (which implies surprise). Ease is the absence of friction. The best compliment for an active lease experience is 'I barely had to think about it.'

do: Shrink notification copy to the minimum: 'Stay confirmed: Mon Mar 10 - Fri Mar 14' is enough
Use the same language every week for consistency: the guest should recognize the notification format without reading it closely
Make date changes feel casual: 'Need to adjust? Tap here.' not 'Submit a Date Modification Request'
Embed review prompts in the natural flow: 'How was this week?' with a one-tap rating scale inside the Stays Manager
dont: Send multi-paragraph notifications for routine events: a weekly stay confirmation should never be longer than a text message
Use formal or contractual language for routine actions: 'cleaning verification' feels like a compliance requirement; 'quick photo before you leave' feels like a friendly reminder
Interrupt the guest's routine with modal popups or full-screen prompts: every interruption during the active lease erodes the feeling of ease
Send notifications at arbitrary times: align with the guest's rhythm (Friday departure, Monday arrival)
copy_guidelines.example_good: Stay confirmed: Mon Mar 10 - Fri Mar 14. Quick photo before you leave Friday?
copy_guidelines.example_bad: BOOKING CONFIRMATION: Your upcoming stay at Rita's Condo (Listing #4892) has been confirmed for the period of March 10-14, 2026. Please remember to upload cleaning verification photos upon departure as outlined in Section 4.2 of your lease agreement.

animation_feel.feel_description: During the active lease, animations should be nearly invisible. Stays Manager updates refresh without perceptible motion. Date changes apply with a quick, businesslike transition. Notifications appear and can be dismissed with a single gesture. Nothing demands a second look. The emotional quality is that of a well-oiled mechanism: you know it is working because you do not notice it working.

tension_relief.tension_point: Each Monday arrival is a micro-tension: 'Is my stay confirmed? Is the space still as I left it? Has anything changed?'
tension_relief.relief_point: The Stays Manager shows the current week's status on launch. The guest sees her confirmed dates, the host's last message, and any actions due. The relief is: 'Everything is as expected. I can go about my day.'
tension_relief.timing: Stays Manager loads within 1 second. Weekly confirmation notification arrives Sunday evening before the Monday return. Date change confirmations appear within minutes.

personalization_signals: After the first 2 weeks, suppress the cancellation guarantee banner entirely and replace the detailed House Manual with a compact reference card
If the guest's schedule is consistent (always Mon-Fri), auto-confirm recurring dates and show a simple 'Auto-confirmed for next week' message
If the friend's medical appointment schedule shifts, allow the proxy (Susan) to adjust dates with the same one-tap presets, and notify the friend: 'Susan updated your dates to Tue-Sat this week'

anti_patterns.pattern: Full-attention notifications for every routine event during an 8-week stay
anti_patterns.reason: An 8-week stay at 5 nights per week generates 8 weekly confirmations, 8 cleaning reminders, 8 review prompts, and 8+ payment confirmations. If each demands the same notification weight as the initial booking, the guest receives 30+ high-attention notifications. This produces resentment, not ease. Norman's feedback hierarchy must be applied: routine events get quiet in-app updates; only exceptions get push notifications.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Week 5: push notification with sound: 'Your stay at Rita's Condo is confirmed for March 10-14! Remember to upload cleaning photos by Friday at 6 PM. Don't forget to leave a review!'

anti_patterns.pattern: Requiring the guest to re-confirm dates every week through a multi-step form
anti_patterns.reason: If the guest's schedule is consistent, requiring weekly re-confirmation is busy work that converts ease into obligation. The platform should auto-confirm recurring patterns and only require interaction when the guest wants to change something. The emotional principle is: do not turn a routine into a task.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Every Sunday: 'Please confirm your upcoming stay. Step 1: Verify dates. Step 2: Confirm schedule. Step 3: Accept terms. Submit.'

elements.title: Acknowledged Partnership in Proxy Booking
elements.problem: Susan is performing an act of care: she is finding housing for a friend who is coming from Oregon for medical appointments. She is coordinating logistics, negotiating terms, offering to pay a deposit, and planning to set up all her friend's appointments. The platform's single-user model not only fails to support her operationally (as addressed in previous layers) but also fails to acknowledge her emotionally. Susan is a partner in this booking, not a side character. When the platform addresses only the guest-occupant and ignores the coordinator, Susan feels invisible. Norman's signifier principle has an emotional implication: when the platform does not signify the proxy role, it communicates 'this role does not exist here' which is emotionally equivalent to 'you do not matter.' The emotional challenge is not just accommodating the proxy pattern but honoring the human relationship behind it.
elements.solution: The platform must acknowledge the proxy's role with emotional intelligence, not just functional support. When Susan selects 'Booking for someone else,' the platform should immediately communicate 'we support this' through its tone and structure. The coordinator's name appears throughout the booking: 'Managed by Susan' is visible on the booking summary. Status updates to Susan reference her role: 'Rita accepted your proposal for [Friend's Name]' not just 'Proposal accepted.' During the active lease, Susan receives coordinator-appropriate feedback that acknowledges her ongoing involvement: 'Your guest arrived Monday' or '[Friend's Name]'s stay this week went smoothly.' The emotional principle is: proxy bookers are performing an act of service for someone they care about. The platform should make them feel seen and valued for that act, not treated as an edge case or an afterthought.

evidence.quote: I have a friend of mine who was coming from Oregon.
evidence.insight: Susan introduces herself not through her own needs but through her friend's. Her emotional identity in this booking is 'helper' and 'protector.' The platform must honor this identity by addressing her as such, not by forcing her into the 'guest' role.

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: Susan is setting up medical appointments for her friend. This is not transactional coordination. It is an act of care. The platform's tone should reflect an awareness that behind this booking is a human relationship, not just a business transaction.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: The signifier 'Booking for someone else' communicates that the platform understands the proxy role exists. But emotional acknowledgment goes further: throughout the journey, the coordinator must see their name, their role, and their contribution reflected in the interface. The alternative actions ('View guest details,' 'Send check-in info to [Friend]') must signify the proxy's agency.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products.
evidence.insight: The proxy booking requires a conceptual model that includes TWO people, not one. Emotionally, the coordinator must see a model where their role is integral: 'Susan manages the booking; [Friend] stays at the space.' Both roles are necessary, both are visible, both are valued.

elements.emotion_rationale: Susan is performing a selfless act of coordination for a vulnerable friend. Her emotional need is not trust or control (those are addressed by other elements) but recognition: the feeling that the platform sees her role, values her contribution, and treats her as a partner in the booking rather than a workaround to the single-user model. Recognition is the emotion that converts a proxy from 'someone working around the system' to 'someone the system was built for.'

do: Name both roles throughout: 'Managed by Susan for [Friend's Name]' on the booking summary
Use role-specific language in notifications: 'Rita accepted your proposal for [Friend]' to Susan; 'Your stay is confirmed, managed by Susan' to the friend
Acknowledge ongoing involvement: 'Your guest arrived Monday' recognizes Susan's role without being saccharine
Frame the proxy toggle as a positive feature: 'Booking for someone else? We support that.' not 'Is this booking for a different person?'
dont: Treat the proxy as a secondary user: hiding the coordinator's name or sending only the occupant's confirmation undermines the proxy's sense of involvement
Use generic role labels: 'Account Holder' or 'Primary Contact' are bureaucratic. 'You' and your friend's actual name are human.
Ignore the proxy during the active lease: if Susan stops receiving updates, she feels forgotten. She initiated this entire booking.
Sentimentalize the proxy relationship: 'We know you care about your friend' is presumptuous. Simply reflecting the relationship through the interface ('Managed by Susan') is sufficient.
copy_guidelines.example_good: Managed by Susan. Rita accepted your proposal for [Friend's Name]. Check-in details will go to [Friend] on March 2. Payment confirmation sent to you.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Booking confirmed. Guest: [Friend's Name]. For questions, contact the account holder.

animation_feel.feel_description: The role toggle at the start of the flow uses a gentle scale and color transition that feels like the platform opening a door: 'You want to book for someone else? Come right in.' The coordinator badge ('Managed by Susan') appears with the same settled motion as other structural elements. Role switches between coordinator and occupant views use a soft cross-fade that feels like turning a page, not navigating to a new place.

tension_relief.tension_point: Susan does not know if the platform can handle a proxy booking. The tension is: 'Can I even do this? Do I have to pretend to be my friend?'
tension_relief.relief_point: The 'Booking for someone else' toggle appears early in the flow, and selecting it restructures the form to accommodate both roles. The relief is: 'They built this for people like me.'
tension_relief.timing: The role toggle must be visible within the first 3 seconds of the proposal flow. If the guest has to search for a proxy option, the tension has already resolved into frustration.

personalization_signals: If Susan adds her friend's name, use it consistently everywhere: '[Friend's Name]'s stay' not 'Guest's stay'
Send Susan a summary at the end of each week: '[Friend's Name] completed 5 nights this week. Next week: Mon Mar 17 - Fri Mar 21.'
If Susan's friend checks in or flags an issue, notify Susan immediately with a role-appropriate message: '[Friend's Name] checked in at 6:00 PM. Everything looks good.'

anti_patterns.pattern: Platform addresses all communications to the occupant and copies the coordinator as an afterthought
anti_patterns.reason: If Susan only receives CC'd notifications that are written for her friend, she feels like a bystander in a process she initiated. The coordinator's notifications should be written for the coordinator: 'Your guest arrived' not a forwarded copy of 'Welcome to your stay!'
anti_patterns.example_bad: Email to Susan: 'Hi [Friend's Name], welcome to Rita's condo! Here are your check-in details...' (with Susan on CC)

anti_patterns.pattern: Proxy booking requires both parties to create accounts before any action can be taken
anti_patterns.reason: Susan's friend is in Oregon with medical appointments. Requiring the friend to create an account, verify an email, and complete a profile before Susan can even submit a proposal creates friction that punishes the proxy for being helpful. Susan must be able to complete the booking solo and invite the friend later.
anti_patterns.example_bad: 'To complete this proxy booking, please have your guest create an account first. We will send them an invitation email. Once they have verified their email and completed their profile, you can proceed with your proposal.'

elements.name: Commute Impact Snapshot Hero
elements.problem_it_solves: It reframes discovery from generic room browsing to a quantified commute-cost problem users can immediately recognize and act on.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Craigslist starts with listings; Split Lease starts with the economic pain of hybrid commuting and then routes users into room-sharing as the category answer.
elements.description: This hero section calculates and visualizes a user's current weekly commute burden versus a nearby split-lease option. It presents savings in dollars, hours, and stress in one glance, then recommends matching neighborhoods and days-of-week patterns. The component acts as a category-creation front door by making users say, 'This is my problem.'

visual_spec.layout: Two-column grid (insight panel + action panel) in a 960px max-width container; collapses to one column on mobile.
visual_spec.background: Gradient surface using bg-off-white to white with subtle radial purple glow.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with inner highlight line in rgba(140,104,238,0.3).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple anchors trust and category framing; secondary purple drives key numbers and actions; accent purple highlights deltas and opportunity tags.

interaction_spec.default_state: User sees commute baseline, split-lease scenario, and a primary CTA to view matched rooms near office days.
interaction_spec.hover: Savings tiles lift by 2px with purple shadow and stronger accent ring.
interaction_spec.click: CTA opens filtered inventory for selected office area and weekday pattern.
interaction_spec.animation: Load-in uses 300ms fade-up; number counters animate over 700ms ease-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: Cards stack vertically; CTA spans full width; metric tiles switch from 3 columns to 1 column under 600px.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Switch to a Split Lease near Flatiron for Mon-Wed and cut 37 commuting hours this month.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Buttons: 'Show rooms near 23rd St', 'Adjust my office days'. Helper: 'Based on 12 round trips from Jersey City + current transit costs.'
do: Use concrete money-and-time numbers before talking about listings.
Speak in recurring weekly patterns (Mon-Wed, Tue-Thu), not one-time trips.
Keep the frame on solved pain, not generic affordability.
dont: Do not open with property inventory counts.
Do not use vague claims like 'save big'.
Do not force signup before showing the first savings estimate.

elements.name: Progressive Trust Ledger Card
elements.problem_it_solves: It replaces binary, guesswork trust with an accumulating, legible trust history that updates from pre-contact through active stay.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Competitors offer anonymity or static badges; this element shows trust as a live timeline of verified events and reliability behavior.
elements.description: This card appears on listing and proposal surfaces to show both host and guest trust progression. It combines identity verification, response reliability, payment consistency, and stay behavior milestones in one compact ledger view. Users can inspect evidence and timestamps instead of relying on gut feel.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card with header, score strip, and four timeline nodes using left-rail progression.
visual_spec.background: White card with subtle purple top gradient.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with 2px top border in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple marks verified nodes; accent purple marks in-progress nodes; muted gray marks upcoming trust events.

interaction_spec.default_state: Shows trust level summary and current node status with visible evidence count.
interaction_spec.hover: Node rows raise contrast and show inline source details.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a node opens a mini detail drawer with verification method and date.
interaction_spec.animation: Timeline nodes animate in staggered 80ms intervals; active node pulse loops every 3s.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, trust score and nodes stack with full-width tappable rows (48px min height).

copy_spec.secondary_text: Trust built across 5 verified events, not one profile badge.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Nodes: 'ID + income verified', 'Responds in 2.1h average', 'Payment reliability 100%', '2 completed stays with no disputes'.
do: Show evidence source and recency for every trust claim.
Use plain language for what each verification means in practice.
Keep trust progression visible in both listing and proposal contexts.
dont: Do not collapse trust to a single checkmark.
Do not show private raw financial details.
Do not hide unresolved trust steps.

elements.name: Structured Proposal Composer
elements.problem_it_solves: It replaces the unstructured email void with a comparable proposal format and explicit response states for both sides.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Instead of chat-like freeform messaging, this creates a negotiation protocol with structured fields, delivery certainty, and next-state clarity.
elements.description: This form is the first message and negotiation instrument in one component. Guests submit dates, weekly pattern, budget, profile confidence, and constraints in a host-friendly summary block. Hosts then respond using clear states (accept, counter, decline, waitlist) with expected timing visible to both parties.

visual_spec.layout: Single-column proposal form with grouped blocks and sticky summary/action footer.
visual_spec.background: White form card on off-white surface with light purple section dividers.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with focus ring in rgba(109,49,194,0.18).
visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple indicates completion and active fields; accent purple marks counter-offer hints; neutral grays hold supporting metadata.

interaction_spec.default_state: Core fields visible with prefill from profile and disabled submit until required fields are complete.
interaction_spec.hover: Field groups get subtle purple border lift; state chips brighten.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting dates/pattern updates summary in real time; submit transitions to Delivered state with timestamp.
interaction_spec.animation: Field completion check appears with 150ms fade; submit success uses 220ms scale-in chip.
interaction_spec.responsive: Mobile uses full-width controls and fixed bottom action bar with 48px minimum tap targets.

copy_spec.primary_text: Send a structured proposal to Priya
copy_spec.secondary_text: Hosts respond faster when dates, schedule, and budget are clear up front.
copy_spec.micro_copy: States: 'Delivered', 'Host reviewing', 'Counter received', 'Accepted'. Buttons: 'Send proposal', 'Save draft', 'Counter terms'.
do: Pre-fill known identity and work schedule details.
Show host response expectation before submit.
Use explicit state language after submit.
dont: Do not drop users into an empty text box.
Do not hide delivery or read status.
Do not require long-form writing to submit first intent.

elements.name: Active Stay Operations Board
elements.problem_it_solves: It prevents the post-contact drop-off by giving hosts and guests one shared operating layer for payments, date changes, issues, and continuity memory.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Competitors abandon the relationship at listing/contact; this board makes the actual stay a managed, data-generating phase with compounding convenience.
elements.description: This board sits in Stays Manager and coordinates all active-lease operations in a single timeline surface. It includes current week plan, payment state, issue queue, and next-cycle date controls with role ownership labels. The board keeps both parties aligned and preserves memory for faster repeat cycles.

visual_spec.layout: Three-column desktop board (timeline, operations, memory) that collapses to stacked cards on mobile.
visual_spec.background: Off-white page with white cards and purple-highlighted active row.
visual_spec.border: Cards use 1px var(--border-color); active row uses 2px left border in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple frames board hierarchy; secondary purple signals actionable status; accent purple marks upcoming cycle changes.

interaction_spec.default_state: Current cycle row is active with next actions and owner labels (Host / Guest / Split Lease).
interaction_spec.hover: Rows highlight with subtle purple background and show quick actions.
interaction_spec.click: Users can confirm payment, request date swap, or open issue thread inline.
interaction_spec.animation: Timeline entries slide in from bottom over 250ms; status chips animate color transition over 150ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: Columns stack; quick actions move to sticky bottom action strip with 48px controls.

copy_spec.primary_text: Your active stay, managed week by week
copy_spec.secondary_text: No off-platform guesswork: payments, schedule changes, and issue handling stay in one shared board.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Actions: 'Confirm this week's payment', 'Swap Wed for Thu', 'Report issue', 'View move-out checklist'.

elements.name: Trust Ledger Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: On Furnished Finder, a host who has successfully housed 50 travel nurses looks identical to a host who listed yesterday. There is no mechanism for trust to compound -- no reviews, no response metrics, no verification depth. Guests make high-stakes decisions (where to live for 3 months, $3,000-6,000 commitment) with zero quality signals. The Trust Ledger Profile Card replaces the trust vacuum with a compounding credential display that grows richer with every completed stay.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor in mid-term housing has a trust profile that compounds over time. Airbnb has Superhost for short stays but it resets quarterly and has no temporal depth. FF has no trust signals at all. elements.name: Extension Flow Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Assignment extensions are the default behavior in travel nursing ('three to four months then extend -- that's very typical'), yet no platform supports them. On Furnished Finder, extending requires: a phone call to the host, renegotiation of terms, a new lease or amendment, and updated deposit arrangements. The Extension Flow Card makes the most predictable event in mid-term housing a one-tap operation within the Stays Manager.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No mid-term housing platform has a structured extension workflow. Airbnb's 'Modify Trip' is designed for short stays and requires host approval through a multi-step flow. FF has no extension infrastructure at all. Split Lease's Extension Flow Card treats extensions as first-class citizens in the stay lifecycle -- because they are the norm, not the exception.
elements.description: A contextual card that appears in the Stays Manager when the lease end date is within 3 weeks. It shows the current lease timeline, the host's pre-set extension policy (auto-renew at same terms, requires approval, not available), and a one-tap 'Extend Stay' action. If the host allows auto-renewal, the guest taps once and the lease extends by the pre-set increment (typically 4 weeks). If approval is required, the tap sends a structured extension request to the host with pre-filled terms. The card also shows the host's response time metric to set expectations. After extension, the Stays Manager timeline updates seamlessly.

elements.name: Smart Agreement Builder
elements.problem_it_solves: Every host-guest pair on Furnished Finder reinvents the same lease from scratch. Thousands of functionally identical agreements are drafted independently each month, all addressing the same predictable issues. The Smart Agreement Builder pre-fills a structured agreement based on property type, stay duration, and state law, transforming a construction task into a confirmation task.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Thiel: 'PayPal made buying and selling on eBay at least 10 times better.' FF's booking process is Craigslist with better SEO -- call a stranger, negotiate from scratch, use Venmo. The Smart Agreement Builder is the PayPal of mid-term housing: it controls the transaction layer that FF deliberately abandoned. No competitor pre-structures the negotiation based on the specific use case.
elements.description: A guided agreement interface embedded in the proposal flow. When a guest submits a proposal, the system generates a pre-filled agreement based on: property location (state-specific terms), stay duration (lease vs. sublease thresholds), property type (shared vs. standalone), and both parties' profiles. The agreement displays as a clean, scannable summary with key terms highlighted: dates, monthly rent, deposit amount, utility policy, cleaning expectations, early termination clause, and extension terms. Both host and guest can toggle specific terms (e.g., switch from 'utilities included' to '$150 utility cap') without starting from scratch. Changes are tracked and visible to both parties. Once both agree, the agreement is signed electronically and becomes a living document in the Stays Manager.

elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No mid-term housing platform builds longitudinal intelligence. A 'Your Preferences' section shows learned preferences (inferred from past stays + explicitly set): neighborhood type, price range, must-have amenities, commute tolerance. These preferences auto-populate search filters when the guest starts a new search. A 'Recommended for You' section shows new listings that match the learned profile. elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder asks guests to commit $3,000-6,000 based on photos and a star rating -- a full product commitment without an MVP test. This card reframes the trial night as a hypothesis test and shows the guest their confidence level building step by step.

elements.description: A compact card displayed during the proposal creation flow that shows the guest their current 'confidence level' in the booking decision. Each step shows validated/not-yet status. Completing more steps increases the confidence indicator. The card does not block booking -- guests can proceed at any confidence level -- but it frames the trial night as the rationale step, not the exceptional one.

elements.name: Outcomes Dashboard: What We've Learned
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder measured progress by unit count (outputs) instead of guest satisfaction (outcomes). This dashboard makes Split Lease's hypothesis-driven learning visible: what experiments are running, what we've learned, and what's changing as a result.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No accommodation platform shares its learning process with users. Hotels announce new amenities. Airbnb updates policies. Split Lease shows what hypotheses it tested, what it learned, and what changed -- positioning itself as a platform that gets better because it listens, not because it scales.
elements.description: A compact 'What We've Learned' section that appears on the guest's account dashboard (and optionally on the host dashboard). It shows 2-3 recent product improvements framed as hypothesis results: 'We tested: weekly check-in messages during stays. We learned: guests who received check-ins rated their stays 0.4 points higher. We changed: all stays now include a Week 2 check-in from the host.' Each entry links the improvement back to actual guest feedback, closing the build-measure-learn loop visibly. The section updates monthly and rotates entries.

do: Use specific numbers ('0.4 points higher', '23% more responses') not vague claims
Credit guest feedback explicitly -- 'Based on feedback from 47 guests'
Frame improvements as evidence-based, not opinion-based
dont: Never announce features without showing the hypothesis that led to them
Never use marketing language ('exciting new feature!') -- use learning language ('we tested and learned')
Never show improvements that cannot be traced to real feedback

elements.html_css:

Here's what living here actually feels like, from the people who know.

East-facing windows fill the bedroom with light by 7am. The coffee shop on Amsterdam Ave opens at 6:30 -- it's a 2-minute walk. The 1 train at 79th Street is three blocks south; you'll be at Penn Station in 18 minutes.

Your Weekend

before_after.before: HotPads: every search session starts from zero. No 'viewed before' indicators, no 'new since last visit' badges, no session continuity. Users must recall from memory which listings they already evaluated.
before_after.after: Split Lease: returning users see their search journey summarized -- what they viewed, what's new, where they stopped. Recognition replaces recall (Thing #22). The search feels like a partnership, not a reset.

elements.name: Comparison Tray (4-Item Working Memory Scaffold)
elements.problem_it_solves: Users cannot meaningfully compare more than 4 listings at once (Thing #20), yet platforms present 30+ with no comparison tooling, forcing shallow satisficing instead of deep evaluation.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform provides structured comparison limited to working memory capacity. The 4-item tray is not arbitrary -- it is neurologically determined. By designing for the brain's actual limit, Split Lease enables better decisions than any platform showing more options.
elements.description: A floating bottom tray that holds up to 4 listing cards for side-by-side comparison. When the guest adds a listing to the tray, it appears as a compact thumbnail. At 4 items, the tray shows a 'Compare Now' action and prevents adding more without removing one (enforcing the working memory limit). The compare view highlights only the attributes that differ between listings, reducing cognitive load.

visual_spec.layout: Fixed bottom bar, 72px height, flex row. Listing thumbnails on the left, action buttons on the right.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with var(--shadow-xl) for strong elevation

typography.heading: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, var(--text-dark) -- listing names in tray
typography.body: Inter, 11px, 400 weight, var(--text-gray) -- prices in tray
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, white -- compare button text

visual_spec.color_usage: White background with strong purple-tinted shadow for clear elevation. Secondary purple on Compare button. Accent purple on the item count badge. Subtle purple border on selected item thumbnails.

interaction_spec.default_state: Hidden when empty. Slides up when first listing is added. Shows compact listing thumbnails.
interaction_spec.hover: Tray items show a remove (x) button on hover. Compare button shifts to accent-purple.
interaction_spec.click: Compare Now: opens full-screen comparison view. Thumbnail: navigates to that listing. X button: removes from tray with slide-out animation.
interaction_spec.animation: Tray entrance: slide-up from bottom, 300ms ease-out. Items enter with 150ms scale-up. Items exit with 200ms scale-down and slide-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, tray becomes a compact pill showing count only ('3 to compare'). Tap expands to full tray view as an overlay.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Add up to 4 listings to compare side by side
micro_copy: Tray full -- remove one to add another
do: Show the 4-item limit as a feature, not a constraint
Highlight what differs between listings, not what's the same
dont: Never allow more than 4 items
Never force comparison -- the tray is optional
Never auto-add listings to the tray

before_after.after: Split Lease: a floating tray holds exactly 4 listings (the working memory limit). Side-by-side comparison highlights only what differs. The platform does the scaffolding work the brain cannot.

elements.name: Proposal Status Pipeline
elements.problem_it_solves: After submitting a proposal, guests enter a black box with zero progress visibility, destroying the three motivation drivers (progress, mastery, control) at peak investment.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform shows where your inquiry stands in a process. The status pipeline transforms the most anxious moment of rental search -- the wait after inquiry -- into a structured journey with clear milestones. This directly activates the goal gradient effect (Thing #50): users feel more motivated as they see progress toward a goal.
elements.description: A horizontal pipeline showing 4-5 stages of the proposal lifecycle: Sent, Viewed, Responding, Counter-Offer/Accepted, and Confirmed. Each stage has a timestamp, an icon, and a brief description. The current stage is highlighted in accent purple with a subtle pulse animation. Previous stages show completion checkmarks. Future stages are greyed but visible, giving the guest a mental model of the full process.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal flexbox pipeline, max-width 720px, centered. Stages connected by lines. Full card wrapping the pipeline.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) for the card, var(--bg-off-white) for the page

spacing.gap: Stage circles are evenly distributed across the pipeline width

visual_spec.color_usage: Completed stages use success purple (#4B47CE) for checkmarks. Current stage uses accent purple with pulse. Future stages use light gray. The connecting line transitions from purple (completed) to gray (upcoming).

interaction_spec.default_state: Pipeline shows all stages with current stage highlighted and pulsing
interaction_spec.hover: Completed stages show tooltip with timestamp and detail on hover. Current stage shows expected next action.
interaction_spec.click: Current stage expands to show detail card with host activity info and next steps.
interaction_spec.animation: Current stage has a subtle pulse (opacity 0.7 to 1.0, 2s infinite). Stage transitions animate with a 500ms progress fill along the connecting line.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (< 600px), pipeline converts to a vertical timeline with stages stacked. Active stage is expanded, others are collapsed.

Show expected timelines based on host history
Celebrate progress at each stage ('Sarah viewed your proposal!')
dont: Never show fake progress
Never say 'Under Review' when nothing is happening
Never hide the stage names -- transparency is the trust signal

before_after.after: Split Lease: a live status pipeline shows exactly where the proposal stands. 'Viewed by Host' with a timestamp. 'Sarah typically responds in 4 hours.' elements.name: Active Stay Weekly Check-In Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing platforms disappear at move-in, abandoning the longest phase of the rental lifecycle and missing the habit-formation window that builds loyalty for the next search.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform has any involvement in the active tenancy. The weekly check-in card is the atomic unit of active-stay engagement: a 15-second interaction that confirms the upcoming stay, surfaces any actions needed, and captures a one-tap micro-review. After 13 repetitions (one per week in a standard quarter), the habit is formed.
elements.description: A card that appears in the Stays Manager each week, showing the upcoming stay dates, host name, a 'Confirm This Week' button, and a one-tap mood indicator from the previous stay. The card is designed for sub-30-second interaction: glance at dates, confirm, rate, done. The mood indicator is a simple 3-option scale (great/fine/concern) that accumulates into a temporal narrative of the living experience.

interaction_spec.hover: Confirm button brightens. Day badges show tooltip with date.

interaction_spec.animation: Confirm: button morphs from 'Confirm This Week' to a checkmark with a 200ms scale-bounce. Micro-review selection: selected option scales to 1.1x briefly then settles.

elements.name: Resident Social Proof Badge (Micro-Review Accumulator)
elements.problem_it_solves: Zero social proof exists at the trust-critical moment of listing evaluation, forcing guests to make $20,000+ annual commitments based on photos and specs alone.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform for medium/long-term stays displays resident reviews on listing pages. The micro-review accumulator takes the weekly one-tap reviews from active guests and surfaces them as a temporal narrative on the listing: not a single star rating, but a story of how the experience unfolded over weeks.
elements.description: A compact badge component that appears on listing cards in search results and prominently on the listing detail page. It shows the aggregate rating, number of reviews, and a micro-quote from the most recent review. On the detail page, it expands to show the temporal narrative: a timeline of weekly micro-reviews showing how satisfaction evolved over the stay.

spacing.padding: 6px 12px for compact badge. var(--spacing-xl) for expanded section.

visual_spec.color_usage: Success purple (#4B47CE) for the rating number -- aligning with the trust signal palette. Subtle chat-purple tinting on the badge border. The temporal timeline uses accent purple dots for each weekly review.

interaction_spec.animation: Badge entrance: subtle scale from 0.95 to 1.0 with 200ms ease-out. Timeline expansion: height animation with 300ms ease-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: Compact badge stays inline on all sizes. Expanded timeline stacks vertically on mobile.

dont: Never fabricate reviews
Never show reviews older than 6 months as 'recent'
Never hide negative feedback -- surface it with the host's response

elements.name: House Welcome Card: Pre-Move-In Community Activation
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests move into shared houses with zero knowledge of who they will live with -- the anti-magic moment that PadSplit normalizes.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform introduces you to your housemate before you arrive. This card transforms the anxious gap between acceptance and move-in into a warm social preview that builds trust before the first handshake.
elements.description: A card shown to guests after their proposal is accepted, displaying their co-tenant's anonymized profile: work schedule pattern, lifestyle preferences (quiet/social, early bird/night owl), a short personal intro, and their Passport score if they have one. elements.name: Engagement Ladder Progress Strip
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit's member experience is a flatline -- month 1 and month 12 are identical. There is no progressive value, no engagement ladder, no reason to deepen engagement over time.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform rewards tenure with progressively valuable capabilities. This strip transforms the Stays Manager from a billing portal into an engagement engine that reveals new value at each milestone.
elements.description: A horizontal progress strip integrated into the Stays Manager dashboard, showing the guest's current engagement tier and what unlocks next. Three tiers visible: 'Getting Settled' (weeks 1-4), 'Established' (weeks 5-8, unlocks coordination tools and co-tenant feedback), and 'House Anchor' (weeks 9+, unlocks profile influence, priority dates, and deposit credit). Current tier is highlighted with a progress indicator. The next unlock is teased with a subtle preview.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width horizontal strip, height 72px. Three tier segments with connecting progress bar. Fits within the Stays Manager header area.
visual_spec.background: Linear gradient from rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.03) to rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.06)
visual_spec.color_usage: Completed tier segments use secondary-purple fill. Current tier uses a pulsing accent-purple dot. Future tiers use muted gray. The progress bar uses a gradient from secondary-purple to accent-purple.

interaction_spec.default_state: Strip shows three tier labels with icons, a progress bar at the current position, and a subtle 'Next: [unlock name]' preview for the upcoming tier.
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering over any tier reveals a tooltip with the full list of capabilities at that tier.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking the current tier opens a detail panel showing earned capabilities, progress toward the next tier, and what actions accelerate progression.
interaction_spec.animation: Progress bar fills with a smooth animation (0.6s ease-out) on page load. Current tier dot pulses gently (2s infinite). Next-tier teaser fades in after progress bar completes.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, tiers stack vertically as a compact timeline. Progress indicator shifts to a vertical bar on the left.

Frame progression as natural tenure recognition, not a grind
dont: Don't use XP, points, or score language -- this isn't a game
Don't show a percentage that makes early weeks feel demotivating ('15% complete')
Don't gate essential features behind tiers -- date changes and basic tools are always available

elements.name: Shared Housing Passport Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit members build zero portable reputation -- months of on-time payments and good behavior generate no transferable value. Every new lease starts from scratch.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform creates a cumulative, portable trust profile. This card is the guest's professional identity in the shared-housing world -- a living document that compounds trust over time and creates real switching costs.
elements.description: A profile card that displays the guest's Shared Housing Passport: a cumulative trust score built from weekly micro-reviews, payment reliability, co-tenant feedback, and tenure across leases. Shows the trust score as a prominent number, a temporal graph of micro-review trends, key metrics (consecutive positive weeks, total leases, payment reliability), and verified trust signals. This card appears on the guest's profile (visible to prospective hosts), on the House Welcome Card (visible to prospective co-tenants), and in search results (as a trust badge).

visual_spec.layout: Card with header badge area, score display, metric strip, and trust timeline. Max-width 380px.
visual_spec.background: #ffffff with a subtle top gradient banner (primary-purple to secondary-purple)
visual_spec.color_usage: Purple gradient header conveys authority and trust. Score uses primary-purple for gravitas. Metric icons use success-color (#4B47CE). Timeline uses secondary-purple for positive weeks, muted gray for neutral.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays the score, top metrics, and a sparkline of recent weeks. Compact view suitable for embedding in other contexts.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates. Sparkline expands to show individual week markers with scores.
interaction_spec.click: Expands to full Passport view with detailed timeline, lease history, and endorsements.
