elements.title: Confidentiality Assurance Module: Visual Trust Gate
elements.problem: Jessica demanded 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement' because Robert hadn't established trust through transparency about relationship protection. Professional hosts (brokers, property managers) operate in environments where protecting client relationships is paramount. If Split Lease bypasses the host and contacts landlords directly, the host loses reputation and revenue. Jessica's defensive posture signals information asymmetry: she doesn't understand how Split Lease's process protects her interests. Visual challenge: How do we proactively address confidentiality concerns through visual design before hosts raise them defensively? Text-heavy legal explanations fail to leverage visual processing advantages for trust-building. Visual trust signals (checkmarks, shields, protective imagery) combined with clear typography hierarchy can communicate 'your relationships are safe' more effectively than paragraphs of text.
elements.solution: Design a visual confidentiality assurance module that uses typography, color, iconography, and spatial hierarchy to communicate relationship protection. Primary visual layer: 'How We Protect Your Relationships' section on broker partnership page. Hero element: shield icon ( 64px) in accent color (#2d5a3d) symbolizing protection. Below shield, three protection principles as vertically stacked cards (surface-warm with border, shadow-sm). Each card shows: checkmark icon ( 24px, accent-bright), principle headline (Instrument Serif 20px bold, ink), explanation (Outfit 16px regular, ink-soft). Visual hierarchy: shield icon  principle headlines  explanations. Spacing: xl (40px) vertical rhythm between cards creates clear separation. Secondary visual layer: Downloadable template confidentiality agreement as prominent CTA button (accent background, surface text, rounded-lg radius). Button shows: document icon ( 20px) + label 'Download Template Agreement' (Outfit 16px bold). Position below protection principles, suggesting logical flow: understand protection  review template  proceed with confidence. Tertiary visual layer: Dashboard 'Relationship Protection' panel using signal-info-bg (#e8f0fa) with signal-info border. Shows recent listing access events as timeline: timestamp (IBM Plex Mono 14px regular, ink-muted) + actor ('Split Lease team member') + action ('viewed your listing') + listing name (Outfit 14px medium, ink). Visual hierarchy: timeline events top-to-bottom (most recent first), 'View all' link at bottom.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement, something, because I have no way of knowing since you're not giving me any of the information of the client.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's defensive demand for legal protection surfaces because Robert hasn't visually established trust. Visual confidentiality module (shield icon + protection principles + template agreement download) addresses this proactively during evaluation, before the call. Hosts arrive at the call already reassured, reducing defensive questioning.

evidence.quote: Jessica explains her process: 'The client signs an agreement with me. I contact the landlord directly. The landlord gives me the keys.'
evidence.insight: Jessica operates in a structured, documented process where legal agreements establish trust gates. Visual design must mirror this professional norm: downloadable template agreement (not hidden, not 'contact us for details') signals Split Lease respects legal documentation as a trust mechanism.

evidence.quote: Consequently, we are trained from birth that obedience to proper authority is right. The essential message fills the parental lessons, the schoolhouse rhymes, stories, and songs of our childhood.
evidence.insight: Legal agreements (confidentiality agreements, broker contracts) are authority symbols in professional contexts. By providing a template agreement proactively and making it visually prominent (document icon + CTA button), Split Lease aligns with Jessica's professional norms, triggering automatic trust.

evidence.quote: Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data. Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.
evidence.insight: Confidentiality assurance design should use rounded corners (rounded-lg: 16px on cards, rounded-lg: 8px on button) to maintain approachability. Shield icon () and checkmarks () are universal trust symbols that communicate protection without corporate formality. Serif typography for principle headlines (Instrument Serif) adds personality vs. rigid sans-serif corporate legal language.

evidence.quote: Trust Gate Documentation: 'Confidentiality assurance is PRIMARY information on broker partnership page (visible before evaluation call begins). Template agreement is SECONDARY (downloadable without signup).'
evidence.insight: Layer 2 defined information hierarchy. Layer 3 translates this into visual hierarchy: shield icon + protection principles (PRIMARY, hero section of broker partnership page, largest visual elements)  template agreement download CTA (SECONDARY, prominent button below principles)  dashboard relationship protection panel (TERTIARY, ongoing visibility of who's accessing listings).

typography: Instrument Serif 20px bold (protection principle headlines)
Outfit 16px regular (principle explanations)
Outfit 16px bold (template agreement button label)
Outfit 14px medium (listing names in dashboard timeline)
IBM Plex Mono 14px regular (timestamps in dashboard timeline)
spacing: xl (40px vertical rhythm between protection principle cards)
md (16px between principle headline and explanation)
sm (8px between checkmark icon and headline)
new_tokens_needed: protection-card-border: 2px solid border (slightly thicker than default 1px for emphasis)
timeline-event-spacing: 20px (specific spacing between timeline events in dashboard panel)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum: Accent-bright (#3a7a52) for checkmark icons on surface-warm = 5.8:1 (AA+). Ink (#1a1714) on surface-warm for headlines = 14.2:1 (AAA). Surface (#ffffff) text on accent (#2d5a3d) button = 7.2:1 (AAA). Signal-info (#2d5a8a) on signal-info-bg (#e8f0fa) for dashboard panel = 6.1:1 (AA+). All interactive elements must meet 3:1 contrast for UI components.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Shield icon is the hero element: largest (64px), positioned top-center, accent color creates visual anchor that communicates 'protection' before any text is read. Protection principle cards follow: vertically stacked (clear top-to-bottom scan order), checkmark icons (24px, accent-bright) provide visual rhythm and reinforce 'yes, these protections are active.' Typography hierarchy within cards: serif headlines (Instrument Serif 20px bold) for authority/personality  sans explanations (Outfit 16px) for clarity. Template agreement CTA button (accent background, rounded-lg) stands out below principles, suggesting logical next step. Dashboard relationship protection panel uses timeline format (top-to-bottom, most recent first) with mono typography for timestamps (IBM Plex Mono signals precision/data) and sans typography for actions (Outfit for readability). White space (xl: 40px between cards) prevents cognitive overload, allowing eye to process each protection principle distinctly.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste-model.md 'Trustworthy, not corporate' principle. Confidentiality assurance is proactive and transparent (shield icon + clear principles + downloadable template) vs. reactive and hidden ('contact us for legal info'). Serif typography for headlines (Instrument Serif) adds personality and approachability vs. rigid corporate legal language. Rounded corners (rounded-lg: 16px on cards, 8px on button) maintain 'warm, not cold' brand personality. Shield icon () and checkmark icons () use universal visual symbols that transcend language barriers, communicating protection intuitively. Dashboard timeline (relationship protection panel) provides ongoing transparency ('here's who's accessed your listings'), reinforcing Split Lease's commitment to openness and host control, aligning with 'Relentless Personalization' principle (UI adapts to host's need for visibility and control).

elements.title: Scarcity Proof Progressive Evidence Accumulation
elements.problem: Robert claimed 'We have too much demand and not enough inventory,' but Jessica recognized this as a sales tactic and responded cautiously ('I'll send a couple of listings by Friday'). Cialdini explains that 'newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind'scarcity must be verified through direct experience, not asserted. If Jessica's test listings receive no proposals within 7 days, she'll conclude demand was oversold. The interaction must convert verbal scarcity claims into progressive evidence accumulation: initial demand proof (within 24 hours of commitment)  real-time engagement metrics (within 48 hours of listing live)  conversion velocity celebration (when proposal arrives). Each evidence layer builds on previous, creating cumulative persuasion through direct experience.
elements.solution: Build progressive evidence accumulation system that responds to host's journey milestones with demand proof. Default state (within 24 hours of evaluation call commitment): Send email with 'Your Waitlist Snapshot' showing 5 active guest searches matching host's inventory profile. Each search displays as card: guest persona icon, budget range (IBM Plex Mono, accent-bright), move-in timeline. Loading state (within 48 hours of listing going live): Dashboard displays real-time engagement metrics with count-up animations: 'Your listing has been viewed by [23] guests' (number counts from 0 to 23 over 800ms using spring easing). Metrics update every 60 seconds with smooth number transitions (not sudden jumps). Success state (when first proposal arrives): Display celebration banner across dashboard top: ' First proposal in 4 days  faster than 7-day average!' with confetti animation (subtle, 2-second duration). Banner includes CTA: 'Review Proposal ' (accent button).

evidence.quote: Robert: 'Right now, the way we operate is if we find we have, unfortunately we have right now too much demand and not enough inventory.'
evidence.insight: Robert's verbal scarcity claim needs experiential validation. Jessica won't fully believe 'too much demand' until she sees her listings receiving proposals. Interaction pattern must convert claim into progressive proof: waitlist snapshot (initial evidence)  engagement metrics (ongoing validation)  proposal arrival (conclusive proof).

evidence.quote: The idea that newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind applies to situations well beyond the bounds of the cookie study.
evidence.insight: Newly experienced scarcity (watching your listing's view count increase in real-time) is more persuasive than described scarcity (being told there's high demand). Interaction must make scarcity visible and dynamic through progressive metric updates, not static claims.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I'll see if I can get a couple [of listings].'
evidence.insight: Jessica commits cautiously ('a couple'), testing whether demand is real. Interaction timing is critical: evidence must arrive within days (not weeks) to validate scarcity claim before host concludes it was oversold. Day 1: waitlist snapshot. Day 2-3: engagement metrics. Day 4-7: proposal arrival (if pricing is good).

evidence.quote: spring: cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1)
evidence.insight: Spring easing for metric count-up animations creates visual drama that emphasizes growing demand. As view count increases from 18  23, spring easing creates slight overshoot at end, drawing eye to the growth and reinforcing 'demand is increasing' message.

evidence.quote: Scarcity Proof Visualization: 'Use spring animation to count up from 0 to actual number, creating visual drama that emphasizes growing demand. Engagement metrics update with smooth number transitions.'
evidence.insight: Layer 3 defined animation style for scarcity proof. Layer 4 adds interaction trigger timing: count-up animation fires on initial page load (0  current value) and on metric updates (every 60 seconds, previous value  new value). Host sees demand growing in real-time through animated feedback.

states.default: Dashboard 'Listing Performance' section displays engagement metrics in stat card format: 'Views: 0', 'Saves: 0', 'Matched Searches: 0' (IBM Plex Mono 32px bold, ink). Below metrics, placeholder text (Outfit 16px, ink-soft): 'Metrics will update within 24 hours of your listing going live.' Default state sets expectations for when evidence will appear.
states.loading: When listing goes live and first metrics arrive (within 48 hours), trigger count-up animations: 'Views' counts from 0  18 over 800ms (spring easing), then 'Saves' counts from 0  3 (staggered by 200ms for cascading effect), then 'Matched Searches' counts from 0  5. During count-up, numbers pulse subtly (scale 1.0  1.05  1.0). Loading state creates visual event that signals 'your listing is getting attention.'
states.empty: If listing has been live for 24 hours but has 0 views (unusual, suggests technical issue), display informational banner (signal-info-bg): 'We're still presenting your listing to guests. Metrics typically appear within 48 hours. [Check listing status ]' Empty state reassures host and provides action path if concerned.
states.error: If metrics API fails or times out, display cached metrics from last successful fetch with timestamp: 'Views: 18 (as of 2 hours ago)' (IBM Plex Mono 32px, ink-muted for timestamp). Below metrics, error banner (signal-danger-bg): 'Unable to load latest data. [Retry]'. Error state preserves last known information while acknowledging staleness.
states.success: When first proposal arrives, trigger celebration sequence: (1) Confetti animation launches from proposal notification area (2-second duration, subtle multi-colored dots using accent, signal-info, signal-warn colors). (2) Banner slides down from top of dashboard (400ms spring easing): ' First proposal in 4 days  faster than 7-day average!' (Instrument Serif 20px bold, accent text on accent-light-bg). (3) Proposal notification badge pulses (scale 1.0  1.3  1.0, 600ms, draws eye). Success state creates micro-celebration that validates scarcity claim through tangible outcome.

elements.transition_principle: Scarcity proof accumulation should feel like evidence building over time, not sudden revelations. Metric count-up animations use staggered timing (200ms delays between metrics) to create cascading effecthost sees metrics populating sequentially, suggesting 'data is arriving.' Spring easing on count-ups creates organic motion that feels less robotic, more human. Celebration sequence (confetti + banner + badge pulse) is orchestrated with intentional timing: confetti draws initial attention, banner provides context, badge pulse directs to action. Each transition reinforces the narrative: 'Demand exists  Your listing is getting attention  A guest wants to book.'

timing.response_target: 800ms for each metric count-up; 200ms stagger between metrics; 2-second confetti animation; 400ms banner slide-down
timing.easing: spring (cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1)) for metric count-up and banner slide; out (cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)) for confetti fade-out
timing.rationale: 800ms count-up is slow enough to be perceived and enjoyed (host watches numbers climb) but fast enough not to feel sluggish. 200ms stagger creates pleasing cascade effect without extending total animation duration excessively. 2-second confetti animation is celebratory without being annoying (auto-dismisses, no manual close needed). Spring easing throughout creates cohesive motion language that signals 'positive, organic growth' vs. mechanical updates.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Evaluation phase (host just committed to sending listings): Waitlist snapshot email is primary scarcity proofshow 5 active guest searches to validate 'too much demand' claim before host even creates listings. Proposal management phase (host has listings live, waiting for proposals): Real-time engagement metrics (views, saves) provide ongoing validation while host waits. Each metric update reinforces 'your listing is being seen.' Active lease phase (proposal arrived, host reviewing): Conversion velocity celebration ('4 days vs. 7-day average') provides comparison that validates scarcity through competitive framing ('your listing was in demand faster than typical').
edge_cases: Host's listing is in low-demand market (small city, unusual property type): Display engagement metrics with market context: 'Views: 8  above average for [market name].' Reframe 'low' absolute numbers as 'good' relative performance to maintain host confidence.

Listing receives high views (50+) but no saves or proposals (suggests pricing issue): After 5 days of this pattern, display guidance banner (signal-warn-bg): 'Your listing has strong visibility (50 views) but guests aren't saving it. Consider reducing price by 10-15% to increase conversion.' Link engagement pattern to actionable recommendation.

Proposal arrives very slowly (15+ days, slower than average): Celebration banner adjusts framing: 'First proposal received! Here's the guest profile for your review.' (No velocity comparison if it's unflattering). Celebration focuses on outcome (proposal arrived) not timing.

Multiple proposals arrive simultaneously (3 proposals in same day): Celebration banner emphasizes competition: ' 3 proposals in 24 hours! Your listing is in high demand. Review proposals to choose best fit.' Scarcity framing shifts from 'demand exists' to 'competitive demand' (Cialdini: demand-driven scarcity is most powerful).

Host has multiple listings, varying performance: Dashboard shows comparative metrics: 'Listing A: 23 views. Listing B: 8 views (below average).' Comparison creates internal benchmarkhost sees which listings are performing and can investigate why (pricing, photos, description) without platform needing to diagnose.

elements.title: Economic Uncertainty to Confident Commitment
elements.problem: Jessica spent 6+ minutes (06:29-12:52) in economic uncertainty, negotiating pricing because she couldn't model her returns. She challenged Robert's expectations ('For Manhattan, it's very expensive'), asked for benchmarks ('What's the price range?'), and needed multiple clarifications on the markup model. Her emotional state was calculating but anxious: 'Will this yield competitive returns vs. my traditional broker fee?' When Robert finally said 'You give me the price, already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up,' he used autonomy language to build trust but left Jessica pricing blind. She doesn't know what markup is typical, how price-sensitive guests are, or how long conversion takes. Without transparent economics, hosts experience economic anxiety: 'Am I leaving money on the table?' or 'Am I pricing myself out of conversions?' The emotional challenge: how do we transition hosts from economic uncertainty to confident commitment through transparent, interactive ROI modeling?
elements.solution: Design the journey to replace economic anxiety with confident commitment through progressive economic transparency. Evaluation phase: show ROI comparison immediately (traditional broker fee vs. Split Lease commission with multiplier: '4.5x more commission'). Pricing phase: provide interactive calculator that updates in real-time as host adjusts inputs, showing projected commission over 3/6/12 months, conversion timelines for different price points, and recommended markup range based on comparable listings. Listing creation: display pricing confidence indicators (green zone = recommended, yellow = slower conversion, red = rarely converts) with specific data ('Properties at this price convert in 30 days vs. 10-day average for $100-125 range'). Throughout: use precise, data-anchored language (not vague 'competitive returns') and animate value updates with spring easing to create visual drama that emphasizes growing commission.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'What's the price range?' Robert: '$1,450 or $1,500.' Jessica: 'For Manhattan, it's very expensive. I could find something maybe for 2000 a studio for maybe 1900, 2000.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's emotional state during pricing discussion is uncertain and defensive. She's challenging Robert's expectations because she has superior market knowledge but no benchmarks for Split Lease's model. Economic uncertainty manifests as defensive correction: 'You're wrong about Manhattan pricing.'

evidence.quote: Robert: 'You give me the price, which is already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up. You just give me a surprise, including your fees, whatever you feel reasonable.'
evidence.insight: Robert's autonomy language ('whatever you feel reasonable') sounds empowering but emotionally it leaves Jessica unsupported. She's now responsible for pricing success or failure without benchmarks. Emotional state: autonomous but anxious ('What if I get this wrong?').

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker, but I am interested.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's conditional commitment ('I have to run it by my broker') signals residual economic uncertainty. She's interested but doesn't yet have enough data to internally justify the partnership. If economics were crystal clear, she could present a stronger case to her broker.

evidence.quote: Because their positions speak of superior access to information and power, it makes great sense to comply with the wishes of properly constituted authorities.
evidence.insight: Split Lease should position itself as the pricing authority by sharing proprietary conversion data. Transparent data reduces host anxiety by establishing Split Lease as the credible source of 'what pricing works,' allowing hosts to defer to expertise rather than guess.

elements.emotion_rationale: Hosts commit when they feel confident in their economic model, not when they're anxious about whether they're pricing correctly or leaving money on the table.

copy_guidelines.voice: Transparent data partner, not mysterious platform
do: Show concrete ROI comparisons: 'Traditional broker fee: $2,000 upfront. Split Lease model: $50/day markup over 6 months = $9,000 total. You earn 4.5x more.'
Provide specific conversion benchmarks: 'Listings priced at $100-125/day convert in 10 days on average. Above $150/day: 30+ days.'
Explain why recommendations serve host: 'We recommend this price range because it maximizes your total commission through faster conversion and higher occupancy.'
Animate value updates to create visual drama: When host adjusts calculator inputs, commission value counts up from previous to new amount, emphasizing growth
dont: Use vague language: 'Competitive returns' or 'Good earning potential' (too generic, doesn't reduce anxiety)
Withhold conversion data: 'Try different prices and see what works' (shifts risk entirely to host)
Hide revenue conflicts: If Split Lease benefits from higher prices that don't convert, say nothing (destroys trust)
Provide autonomy without benchmarks: 'Whatever you feel is reasonable' (sounds empowering but leaves host anxious)
copy_guidelines.example_good: Based on 150 comparable listings in Manhattan, properties priced at $110-120/day convert in 8 days and generate $19,800 commission over 6 months. Pricing at $150/day typically takes 30 days to convert and generates $27,000 totalhigher commission but longer wait and higher vacancy risk.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You can set whatever price you want! We support your decision and think you'll do great. Just enter your preferred daily rate and we'll take it from there.

animation_feel.feel_description: Satisfying bounce at the end of value transitions that emphasizes the final number. Creates micro-celebration of commission growth that builds emotional confidence: 'Look how much you're earning!'
animation_feel.duration_range: 400-800ms for value count-up animations (slow enough to be perceived and enjoyed, fast enough not to delay workflow)

tension_relief.tension_point: Pricing phase: 'Am I pricing correctly? Will I earn enough? Will my listings convert or sit idle?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Interactive calculator shows projected commission + conversion timeline + comparison to traditional fee, all updating in real-time as host adjusts inputs
tension_relief.timing: Relief arrives immediately when host accesses calculator (within first 30 seconds of pricing exploration). Instant feedback loop: adjust input  see outcome  feel confident.

personalization_signals: Pre-populate calculator with host's actual market data: If host is in Manhattan, show Manhattan-specific conversion benchmarks, not national averages
Reference host's current revenue model: 'Compared to your traditional broker fee of [X], Split Lease would generate [Y] over [Z] months'
Adapt recommendations to host's inventory: 'For your studio listings, we recommend $110-125/day based on 45 comparable properties in your area'

anti_patterns.pattern: Autonomy without support: 'You decide the price, we trust your judgment!'
anti_patterns.reason: Sounds empowering but emotionally abandons the host. They wanted guidance, not full responsibility. Economic anxiety persists: 'What if I get this wrong and nothing converts?'
anti_patterns.example_bad: You're the expert on your market! Set whatever price feels right to you. We'll support whatever you decide.

anti_patterns.pattern: Vague earnings promises: 'Earn more with Split Lease!'
anti_patterns.reason: Generic claims without specific data don't reduce economic anxietythey increase skepticism. Hosts need numbers: how much more, over what timeframe, compared to what.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Split Lease hosts earn significantly more than traditional models. Our innovative approach maximizes your earning potential!

anti_patterns.pattern: Hiding pricing complexity to seem simple
anti_patterns.reason: Professional hosts like Jessica aren't looking for 'simple'they're looking for transparent and data-driven. Hiding conversion data or markup implications to avoid complexity creates anxiety, not confidence.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Don't worry about the details! Just give us your base rent and we'll handle the rest. It's super easy!

elements.title: Communication Overload to Respected Efficiency
elements.problem: At 18:07-18:14, Jessica stated: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.' This brief comment reveals a deeper emotional state: communication overload and the anxiety that comes with it. Jessica is a busy broker managing multiple deals, clients, and properties. Email is where important messages get buried and missed. Her preference for text isn't just convenienceit's a coping mechanism for information overload. If Split Lease defaults to email for time-sensitive notifications (proposals arriving, guest questions), Jessica may miss them entirely, leading to emotional frustration ('Why didn't you tell me?') and practical consequences (lost conversions). The emotional challenge: how do we transition hosts from communication anxiety (fear of missing important messages) to respected efficiency (confidence that Split Lease adapts to their workflow)?
elements.solution: Design the journey to demonstrate respect for host's communication preferences and constraints. Onboarding: explicitly ask how host prefers to receive time-sensitive notifications (email, text, both) and explain the distinction (time-sensitive via preferred channel, non-urgent via email). Make preference persistently visible in dashboard header as badge: ' Text preferred  Change' so host sees constant confirmation their preference is active. Proposal management/active lease: route time-sensitive communications (proposals, guest questions, booking confirmations) through preferred channel and acknowledge this: 'You'll receive this via text, as you requested.' Allow easy preference updates anytime. Throughout: use tone that respects busy professionalsconcise, actionable messages, no fluff.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's emotional state is communication overload. Email is an anxiety source for hermessages get lost, urgent things get missed. Her preference for text is about control and efficiency: text guarantees she'll see it. Emotional need: 'Communicate in ways that work for my workflow.'

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker, but I am interested.'
evidence.insight: Jessica operates in a high-demand professional environment (broker approval required, multiple priorities, building visits mentioned). She doesn't have time to hunt for emails. If Split Lease sends proposals via email and she misses them, she'll blame Split Lease for poor communication, not herself.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I got to go to this building.'
evidence.insight: Jessica is multitasking throughout the callmanaging other deals, visiting buildings, coordinating with clients. Her emotional state is time-constrained and attention-fragmented. Communication needs to be efficient and impossible to miss.

evidence.quote: We like people who are similar to us. Consequently, those who wish to be liked can accomplish that purpose by appearing similar to us in any of a wide variety of ways.
evidence.insight: Honoring Jessica's communication preference is a form of similarity/liking building. By adapting to her workflow (text vs. email), Split Lease demonstrates 'we understand how busy professionals work.' Emotional response: 'They get me. They respect my time.'

elements.emotion_rationale: Hosts experiencing communication overload feel calm when they trust that important messages will reach them through channels they actually monitor, reducing anxiety about missing opportunities.

do: Ask preferences explicitly: 'How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications? Email, text, or both?'
Explain routing logic: 'Time-sensitive notifications (proposals, guest questions) will be sent via text. Non-urgent updates (weekly summaries, platform news) via email.'
Acknowledge preference in action: 'You'll receive this proposal notification via text, as you requested. Change your preference anytime in dashboard settings.'
Keep messages concise and actionable: 'New proposal for your listing at [address]. Guest profile: [persona], [budget], [move-in date]. Review now: [link]'
dont: Assume email is acceptable default: 'We'll send all updates to your email' (ignores professional email overload reality)
Send unnecessary messages: Weekly newsletters, promotional content, platform updates when host just wants transactional notifications (adds to overload)
Use chatty, lengthy language: 'Hey! We're super excited to let you know that...' (wastes busy professional's time)
Bury important information: Subject line 'Split Lease Update' when it's actually a time-sensitive proposal (forces host to open and scan to find urgency)
copy_guidelines.example_good: New proposal: Your listing at 123 Main St received a proposal from Sarah K., young professional, $115/day, moving in Feb 15. Review proposal: [link]. Sent via text as you requested.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Hi Jessica! Hope you're having a great day! We wanted to reach out and let you know that we have some exciting news about one of your listings. A guest has submitted a proposal! We think this is a really great match and you're going to love working with them. Click here to check out all the details in your dashboard. We're here if you have any questions! Talk soon!

animation_feel.feel_description: Smooth, efficient transitions that mirror the emotional state of calm efficiency. No bouncy playfulnessprofessional and assured. Preference badge appears with subtle fade-in, confirmation banner slides down smoothly.
animation_feel.duration_range: 300-400ms for preference-related transitions (badge appearing, confirmation banner sliding in)

tension_relief.tension_point: Onboarding/ongoing: 'Will I miss important notifications because they get buried in email? How do I make sure Split Lease reaches me?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Preference captured during onboarding  preference badge persistently visible in dashboard  first notification acknowledges preference ('sent via text as you requested')
tension_relief.timing: Relief arrives immediately when preference is captured (onboarding) and is reinforced with every notification (ongoing confirmation that system is honoring preference)

personalization_signals: Reference host's stated reason: 'You mentioned email overload. We'll send time-sensitive notifications via text so nothing gets missed.'
Adapt message density to host type: Busy professionals like Jessica get minimal, transactional messages. Part-time landlords might appreciate more educational content.
Display preference prominently: Dashboard header badge (' Text preferred') provides constant reassurance that system remembers and respects their choice

anti_patterns.pattern: One-size-fits-all communication: All hosts get same message frequency and channel
anti_patterns.reason: Ignores reality that different hosts have different communication constraints. Busy professionals experience default email as anxiety-inducing overload. Emotional response: 'They don't respect my time.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: [Host sets text preference but receives all notifications via email anyway] 'We send all our communications via email for consistency.'

anti_patterns.pattern: Lengthy, chatty messages that waste time
anti_patterns.reason: Busy professionals scan messages for actionable information. Long, friendly preambles ('Hope you're having a great day!') force them to hunt for what matters, creating frustration. Emotional response: 'Get to the point.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: Hi Jessica! We hope this message finds you well! We're so excited to be working with you and we just wanted to take a moment to reach out and share some news with you today...

anti_patterns.pattern: No visibility into preference status: Host has to remember what they chose
anti_patterns.reason: If preference isn't persistently visible, host experiences ongoing anxiety: 'Did I set text preference? Is the system actually using it? Should I check settings again?' Cognitive load of remembering creates stress.
anti_patterns.example_bad: [Preference set during onboarding but never shown again. Host receives text notification and thinks: 'Did I set this? Or is it sending to both? I can't remember.']
